children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Thus the first night in the crater passed away.
children.prevalue: Thus the first night in the crater passed away

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The next morning, a grey, heavy, cloudy sky seemed to droop over the summit of the cone. I did not know this first from the appearances of nature, but I found it out by my uncle's impetuous wrath.
children.prevalue: The next morning a grey heavy cloudy sky seemed to droop over the summit of the cone I did not know this first from the appearances of nature but I found it out by my uncle s impetuous wrath

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I soon found out the cause, and hope dawned again in my heart. For this reason.
children.prevalue: I soon found out the cause and hope dawned again in my heart For this reason

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Of the three ways open before us, one had been taken by Saknussemm. The indications of the learned Icelander hinted at in the cryptogram, pointed to this fact that the shadow of Scartaris came to touch that particular way during the latter days of the month of June.
children.prevalue: Of the three ways open before us one had been taken by Saknussemm The indications of the learned Icelander hinted at in the cryptogram pointed to this fact that the shadow of Scartaris came to touch that particular way during the latter days of the month of June

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: That sharp peak might hence be considered as the gnomon of a vast sun dial, the shadow projected from which on a certain day would point out the road to the centre of the earth.
children.prevalue: That sharp peak might hence be considered as the gnomon of a vast sun dial the shadow projected from which on a certain day would point out the road to the centre of the earth

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Now, no sun no shadow, and therefore no guide. Here was June 25. If the sun was clouded for six days we must postpone our visit till next year.
children.prevalue: Now no sun no shadow and therefore no guide Here was June 25 If the sun was clouded for six days we must postpone our visit till next year

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: My limited powers of description would fail, were I to attempt a picture of the Professor's angry impatience. The day wore on, and no shadow came to lay itself along the bottom of the crater. Hans did not move from the spot he had selected; yet he must be asking himself what were we waiting for, if he asked himself anything at all. My uncle spoke not a word to me. His gaze, ever directed upwards, was lost in the grey and misty space beyond.

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: On the 26th nothing yet. Rain mingled with snow was falling all day long. Hans built a hut of pieces of lava. I felt a malicious pleasure in watching the thousand rills and cascades that came tumbling down the sides of the cone, and the deafening continuous din awaked by every stone against which they bounded.

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: My uncle's rage knew no bounds. It was enough to irritate a meeker man than he; for it was foundering almost within the port.
children.prevalue: My uncle s rage knew no bounds It was enough to irritate a meeker man than he for it was foundering almost within the port

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: But Heaven never sends unmixed grief, and for Professor Liedenbrock there was a satisfaction in store proportioned to his desperate anxieties.
children.prevalue: But Heaven never sends unmixed grief and for Professor Liedenbrock there was a satisfaction in store proportioned to his desperate anxieties

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: The next day the sky was again overcast; but on the 29th of June, the last day but one of the month, with the change of the moon came a change of weather. The sun poured a flood of light down the crater. Every hillock, every rock and stone, every projecting surface, had its share of the beaming torrent, and threw its shadow on the ground. Amongst them all, Scartaris laid down his sharp-pointed angular shadow which began to move slowly in the opposite direction to that of the radiant orb.

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: My uncle turned too, and followed it.
children.prevalue: My uncle turned too and followed it

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: At noon, being at its least extent, it came and softly fell upon the edge of the middle chimney.
children.prevalue: At noon being at its least extent it came and softly fell upon the edge of the middle chimney

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: There it is! there it is! shouted the Professor.
children.prevalue: There it is there it is shouted the Professor

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Now for the centre of the globe! he added in Danish.
children.prevalue: Now for the centre of the globe he added in Danish

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I looked at Hans, to hear what he would say.
children.prevalue: I looked at Hans to hear what he would say

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: _Forüt!_ was his tranquil answer.
children.prevalue: Forüt was his tranquil answer

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Forward! replied my uncle.
children.prevalue: Forward replied my uncle

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: It was thirteen minutes past one.
children.prevalue: It was thirteen minutes past one

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: VERTICAL DESCENT
children.prevalue: VERTICAL DESCENT

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Now began our real journey. Hitherto our toil had overcome all difficulties, now difficulties would spring up at every step.
children.prevalue: Now began our real journey Hitherto our toil had overcome all difficulties now difficulties would spring up at every step

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: I had not yet ventured to look down the bottomless pit into which I was about to take a plunge. The supreme hour had come. I might now either share in the enterprise or refuse to move forward. But I was ashamed to recoil in the presence of the hunter. Hans accepted the enterprise with such calmness, such indifference, such perfect disregard of any possible danger that I blushed at the idea of being less brave than he. If I had been alone I might have once more tried the effect of argument; but in the presence of the guide I held my peace; my heart flew back to my sweet Virlandaise, and I approached the central chimney.

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I have already mentioned that it was a hundred feet in diameter, and three hundred feet round. I bent over a projecting rock and gazed down. My hair stood on end with terror. The bewildering feeling of vacuity laid hold upon me. I felt my centre of gravity shifting its place, and giddiness mounting into my brain like drunkenness. There is nothing more treacherous than this attraction down deep abysses. I was just about to drop down, when a hand laid hold of me. It was that of Hans. I suppose I had not taken as many lessons on gulf exploration as I ought to have done in the Frelsers Kirk at Copenhagen.

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: But, however short was my examination of this well, I had taken some account of its conformation. Its almost perpendicular walls were bristling with innumerable projections which would facilitate the descent. But if there was no want of steps, still there was no rail. A rope fastened to the edge of the aperture might have helped us down. But how were we to unfasten it, when arrived at the other end?

children.value: My uncle employed a very simple expedient to obviate this difficulty. He uncoiled a cord of the thickness of a finger, and four hundred feet long; first he dropped half of it down, then he passed it round a lava block that projected conveniently, and threw the other half down the chimney. Each of us could then descend by holding with the hand both halves of the rope, which would not be able to unroll itself from its hold; when two hundred feet down, it would be easy to get possession of the whole of the rope by letting one end go and pulling down by the other. Then the exercise would go on again _ad infinitum_.

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: This is my conclusion. According to exact observations, the increase of temperature in the interior of the globe advances at the rate of one degree (1 4/5° Fahr.) for every hundred feet. But certain local conditions may modify this rate. Thus at Yakoutsk in Siberia the increase of a degree is ascertained to be reached every 36 feet. This difference depends upon the heat-conducting power of the rocks. Moreover, in the neighbourhood of an extinct volcano, through gneiss, it has been observed that the increase of a degree is only attained at every 125 feet. Let us therefore assume this last hypothesis as the most suitable to our situation, and calculate.

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: We were still following the gallery of lava, a real natural staircase, and as gently sloping as those inclined planes which in some old houses are still found instead of flights of steps. And so we went on until 12.17, the, precise moment when we overtook Hans, who had stopped.

children.prevalue: Ah here we are exclaimed my uncle at the very end of the chimney

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I looked around me. We were standing at the intersection of two roads, both dark and narrow. Which were we to take? This was a difficulty.

children.value: Besides there would have been interminable hesitation before this choice of roads; for since there was no indication whatever to guide our choice, we were obliged to trust to chance.
children.prevalue: Besides there would have been interminable hesitation before this choice of roads for since there was no indication whatever to guide our choice we were obliged to trust to chance

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The slope of this gallery was scarcely perceptible, and its sections very unequal. Sometimes we passed a series of arches succeeding each other like the majestic arcades of a gothic cathedral. Here the architects of the middle ages might have found studies for every form of the sacred art which sprang from the development of the pointed arch. A mile farther we had to bow our heads under corniced elliptic arches in the romanesque style; and massive pillars standing out from the wall bent under the spring of the vault that rested heavily upon them. In other places this magnificence gave way to narrow channels between low structures which looked like beaver's huts, and we had to creep along through extremely narrow passages.

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The heat was perfectly bearable. Involuntarily I began to think of its heat when the lava thrown out by Snæfell was boiling and working through this now silent road. I imagined the torrents of fire hurled back at every angle in the gallery, and the accumulation of intensely heated vapours in the midst of this confined channel.

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I only hope, thought I, that this so-called extinct volcano won't take a fancy in his old age to begin his sports again!
children.prevalue: I only hope thought I that this so called extinct volcano won t take a fancy in his old age to begin his sports again

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I abstained from communicating these fears to Professor Liedenbrock. He would never have understood them at all. He had but one idea--forward! He walked, he slid, he scrambled, he tumbled, with a persistency which one could not but admire.
children.prevalue: I abstained from communicating these fears to Professor Liedenbrock He would never have understood them at all He had but one idea forward He walked he slid he scrambled he tumbled with a persistency which one could not but admire

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: By six in the evening, after a not very fatiguing walk, we had gone two leagues south, but scarcely a quarter of a mile down.
children.prevalue: By six in the evening after a not very fatiguing walk we had gone two leagues south but scarcely a quarter of a mile down

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: My uncle said it was time to go to sleep. We ate without talking, and went to sleep without reflection.
children.prevalue: My uncle said it was time to go to sleep We ate without talking and went to sleep without reflection

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Our arrangements for the night were very simple; a railway rug each, into which we rolled ourselves, was our sole covering. We had neither cold nor intrusive visits to fear. Travellers who penetrate into the wilds of central Africa, and into the pathless forests of the New World, are obliged to watch over each other by night. But we enjoyed absolute safety and utter seclusion; no savages or wild beasts infested these silent depths.

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Next morning, we awoke fresh and in good spirits. The road was resumed. As the day before, we followed the path of the lava. It was impossible to tell what rocks we were passing: the tunnel, instead of tending lower, approached more and more nearly to a horizontal direction, I even fancied a slight rise. But about ten this upward tendency became so evident, and therefore so fatiguing, that I was obliged to slacken my pace.

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Well, Axel? demanded the Professor impatiently.
children.prevalue: Well Axel demanded the Professor impatiently

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Well, I cannot stand it any longer, I replied.
children.prevalue: Well I cannot stand it any longer I replied

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: What! after three hours' walk over such easy ground.
children.prevalue: What after three hours walk over such easy ground

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: It may be easy, but it is tiring all the same.
children.prevalue: It may be easy but it is tiring all the same

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What, when we have nothing to do but keep going down!
children.prevalue: What when we have nothing to do but keep going down

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Going up, if you please.
children.prevalue: Going up if you please

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Going up! said my uncle, with a shrug.
children.prevalue: Going up said my uncle with a shrug

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: No doubt, for the last half-hour the inclines have gone the other way, and at this rate we shall soon arrive upon the level soil of Iceland.
children.prevalue: No doubt for the last half hour the inclines have gone the other way and at this rate we shall soon arrive upon the level soil of Iceland

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The Professor nodded slowly and uneasily like a man that declines to be convinced. I tried to resume the conversation. He answered not a word, and gave the signal for a start. I saw that his silence was nothing but ill-humour.

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Still I had courageously shouldered my burden again, and was rapidly following Hans, whom my uncle preceded. I was anxious not to be left behind. My greatest care was not to lose sight of my companions. I shuddered at the thought of being lost in the mazes of this vast subterranean labyrinth.

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Besides, if the ascending road did become steeper, I was comforted with the thought that it was bringing us nearer to the surface. There was hope in this. Every step confirmed me in it, and I was rejoicing at the thought of meeting my little Gräuben again.

children.value: By mid-day there was a change in the appearance of this wall of the gallery. I noticed it by a diminution of the amount of light reflected from the sides; solid rock was appearing in the place of the lava coating. The mass was composed of inclined and sometimes vertical strata. We were passing through rocks of the transition or silurian [1] system.

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: It is evident, I cried, the marine deposits formed in the second period, these shales, limestones, and sandstones. We are turning away from the primary granite. We are just as if we were people of Hamburg going to Lübeck by way of Hanover!

children.prevalue: I had better have kept my observations to myself But my geological instinct was stronger than my prudence and uncle Liedenbrock heard my exclamation

children.value: What's that you are saying? he asked.
children.prevalue: What s that you are saying he asked

children.value: See, I said, pointing to the varied series of sandstones and limestones, and the first indication of slate.
children.prevalue: See I said pointing to the varied series of sandstones and limestones and the first indication of slate

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.prevalue: We are at the period when the first plants and animals appeared

children.name: Paragraph_34

children.prevalue: Do you think so

children.name: Paragraph_35

children.prevalue: Look close and examine

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I obliged the Professor to move his lamp over the walls of the gallery. I expected some signs of astonishment; but he spoke not a word, and went on.

children.value: Had he understood me or not? Did he refuse to admit, out of self-love as an uncle and a philosopher, that he had mistaken his way when he chose the eastern tunnel? or was he determined to examine this passage to its farthest extremity? children.name: Paragraph_38

It could not be otherwise, for in the Silurian age the seas contained at least fifteen hundred vegetable and animal species. In the walls were distinct impressions of fucoids and lycopodites.

children.name: Paragraph_42

children.value: This was only invincible obstinacy. I could hold out no longer. I picked up a perfectly formed shell, which had belonged to an animal not unlike the woodlouse: then, joining my uncle, I said:

children.prevalue: What danger

children.prevalue: The want of water

children.prevalue: THE FIRST SIGNS OF DISTRESS

children.value: In fact, we had to ration ourselves. Our provision of water could not last more than three days. I found that out for certain when supper-time came. And, to our sorrow, we had little reason to expect to find a spring in these transition beds.

children.name: Paragraph_8

children.value: After ten hours' walking I observed a singular deadening of the reflection of our lamps from the side walls. children.prevalue: A coal mine I cried

children.prevalue: A mine without miners my uncle replied

children.value: Who knows? I asked.
children.prevalue: Who knows I asked

children.value: I know, the Professor pronounced decidedly, I am certain that this gallery driven through beds of coal was never pierced by the hand of man. But whether it be the hand of nature or not does not matter. Supper time is come; let us sup.

children.name: Paragraph_17

children.value: On Saturday, at six, we started afresh. In twenty minutes we reached a vast open space; I then knew that the hand of man had not hollowed out this mine; the vaults would have been shored up, and, as it was, they seemed to be held up by a miracle of equilibrium.

children.value: This cavern was about a hundred feet wide and a hundred and fifty in height. A large mass had been rent asunder by a subterranean disturbance. children.value: The whole history of the carboniferous period was written upon these gloomy walls, and a geologist might with ease trace all its diverse phases. The beds of coal were separated by strata of sandstone or compact clays, and appeared crushed under the weight of overlying strata.

children.value: At the age of the world which preceded the secondary period, the earth was clothed with immense vegetable forms, the product of the double influence of tropical heat and constant moisture; a vapoury atmosphere surrounded the earth, still veiling the direct rays of the sun.

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Then came the chemical action of nature; in the depths of the seas the vegetable accumulations first became peat; then, acted upon by generated gases and the heat of fermentation, they underwent a process of complete mineralization.
children.prevalue: Then came the chemical action of nature in the depths of the seas the vegetable accumulations first became peat then acted upon by generated gases and the heat of fermentation they underwent a process of complete mineralization

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Thus were formed those immense coalfields, which nevertheless, are not inexhaustible, and which three centuries at the present accelerated rate of consumption will exhaust unless the industrial world will devise a remedy.
children.prevalue: Thus were formed those immense coalfields which nevertheless are not inexhaustible and which three centuries at the present accelerated rate of consumption will exhaust unless the industrial world will devise a remedy

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: These reflections came into my mind whilst I was contemplating the mineral wealth stored up in this portion of the globe. These no doubt, I thought, will never be discovered; the working of such deep mines would involve too large an outlay, and where would be the use as long as coal is yet spread far and wide near the surface? Such as my eyes behold these virgin stores, such they will be when this world comes to an end.

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: But still we marched on, and I alone was forgetting the length of the way by losing myself in the midst of geological contemplations. The temperature remained what it had been during our passage through the lava and schists. Only my sense of smell was forcibly affected by an odour of protocarburet of hydrogen. I immediately recognised in this gallery the presence of a considerable quantity of the dangerous gas called by miners firedamp, the explosion of which has often occasioned such dreadful catastrophes.

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Happily, our light was from Ruhmkorff's ingenious apparatus. If unfortunately we had explored this gallery with torches, a terrible explosion would have put an end to travelling and travellers at one stroke.
children.prevalue: Happily our light was from Ruhmkorff s ingenious apparatus If unfortunately we had explored this gallery with torches a terrible explosion would have put an end to travelling and travellers at one stroke

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: This excursion through the coal mine lasted till night. My uncle scarcely could restrain his impatience at the horizontal road. The darkness, always deep twenty yards before us, prevented us from estimating the length of the gallery; and I was beginning to think it must be endless, when suddenly at six o'clock a wall very unexpectedly stood before us. Right or left, top or bottom, there was no road farther; we were at the end of a blind alley. Very well, it's all right! cried my uncle, now, at any rate, we shall know what we are about. We are not in Saknussemm's road, and all we have to do is to go back. Let us take a night's rest, and in three days we shall get to the fork in the road. Yes, said I, if we have any strength left. Why not? Because to-morrow we shall have no water. Nor courage either? asked my uncle severely. I dared make no answer.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: COMPASSION FUSES THE PROFESSOR'S HEART
children.prevalue: COMPASSION FUSES THE PROFESSOR S HEART

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Next day we started early. We had to hasten forward. It was a three days' march to the cross roads.
children.prevalue: Next day we started early We had to hasten forward It was a three days march to the cross roads

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: I will not speak of the sufferings we endured in our return. My uncle bore them with the angry impatience of a man obliged to own his weakness; Hans with the resignation of his passive nature; I, I confess, with complaints and expressions of despair. I had no spirit to oppose this ill fortune.
children.prevalue: I will not speak of the sufferings we endured in our return My uncle bore them with the angry impatience of a man obliged to own his weakness Hans with the resignation of his passive nature I I confess with complaints and expressions of despair I had no spirit to oppose this ill fortune

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: As I had foretold, the water failed entirely by the end of the first day's retrograde march. Our fluid aliment was now nothing but gin; but this infernal fluid burned my throat, and I could not even endure the sight of it. I found the temperature and the air stifling. Fatigue paralysed my limbs. More than once I dropped down motionless. Then there was a halt; and my uncle and the Icelander did their best to restore me. But I saw that the former was struggling painfully against excessive fatigue and the tortures of thirst.

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: At last, on Tuesday, July 8, we arrived on our hands and knees, and half dead, at the junction of the two roads. There I dropped like a lifeless lump, extended on the lava soil. It was ten in the morning.
children.prevalue: At last on Tuesday July 8 we arrived on our hands and knees and half dead at the junction of the two roads There I dropped like a lifeless lump extended on the lava soil It was ten in the morning

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Hans and my uncle, clinging to the wall, tried to nibble a few bits of biscuit. Long moans escaped from my swollen lips.
children.prevalue: Hans and my uncle clinging to the wall tried to nibble a few bits of biscuit Long moans escaped from my swollen lips

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: After some time my uncle approached me and raised me in his arms.
children.prevalue: After some time my uncle approached me and raised me in his arms

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Poor boy! said he, in genuine tones of compassion.
children.prevalue: Poor boy said he in genuine tones of compassion

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: I was touched with these words, not being accustomed to see the excitable Professor in a softened mood. I grasped his trembling hands in mine. He let me hold them and looked at me. His eyes were moistened.
children.prevalue: I was touched with these words not being accustomed to see the excitable Professor in a softened mood I grasped his trembling hands in mine He let me hold them and looked at me His eyes were moistened

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Then I saw him take the flask that was hanging at his side. To my amazement he placed it on my lips.
children.prevalue: Then I saw him take the flask that was hanging at his side To my amazement he placed it on my lips

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Drink! said he.
children.prevalue: Drink said he

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Had I heard him? Was my uncle beside himself? I stared at, him stupidly, and felt as if I could not understand him.
children.prevalue: Had I heard him Was my uncle beside himself I stared at him stupidly and felt as if I could not understand him

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Drink! he said again.
children.prevalue: Drink he said again

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: And raising his flask he emptied it every drop between my lips.
children.prevalue: And raising his flask he emptied it every drop between my lips

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Oh! infinite pleasure! a slender sip of water came to moisten my burning mouth. It was but one sip but it was enough to recall my ebbing life.
children.prevalue: Oh infinite pleasure a slender sip of water came to moisten my burning mouth It was but one sip but it was enough to recall my ebbing life

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: I thanked my uncle with clasped hands.
children.prevalue: I thanked my uncle with clasped hands

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Yes, he said, a draught of water; but it is the very last--you hear!--the last. I had kept it as a precious treasure at the bottom of my flask. Twenty times, nay, a hundred times, have I fought against a frightful impulse to drink it off. But no, Axel, I kept it for you.
children.prevalue: Yes he said a draught of water but it is the very last you hear the last I had kept it as a precious treasure at the bottom of my flask Twenty times nay a hundred times have I fought against a frightful impulse to drink it off But no Axel I kept it for you

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: My dear uncle, I said, whilst hot tears trickled down my face.
children.prevalue: My dear uncle I said whilst hot tears trickled down my face

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Yes, my poor boy, I knew that as soon as you arrived at these cross roads you would drop half dead, and I kept my last drop of water to reanimate you.
children.prevalue: Yes my poor boy I knew that as soon as you arrived at these cross roads you would drop half dead and I kept my last drop of water to reanimate you

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Thank you, thank you, I said. Although my thirst was only partially quenched, yet some strength had returned. The muscles of my throat, until then contracted, now relaxed again; and the inflammation of my lips abated somewhat; and I was now able to speak. .
children.prevalue: Thank you thank you I said Although my thirst was only partially quenched yet some strength had returned The muscles of my throat until then contracted now relaxed again and the inflammation of my lips abated somewhat and I was now able to speak

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Let us see, I said, we have now but one thing to do. We have no water; we must go back.
children.prevalue: Let us see I said we have now but one thing to do We have no water we must go back

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: While I spoke my uncle avoided looking at me; he hung his head down; his eyes avoided mine.
children.prevalue: While I spoke my uncle avoided looking at me he hung his head down his eyes avoided mine

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: We must return, I exclaimed vehemently; we must go back on our way to Snæfell. May God give us strength to climb up the crater again!
children.prevalue: We must return I exclaimed vehemently we must go back on our way to Snæfell May God give us strength to climb up the crater again

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Return! said my uncle, as if he was rather answering himself than me.
children.prevalue: Return said my uncle as if he was rather answering himself than me

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Yes, return, without the loss of a minute.
children.prevalue: Yes return without the loss of a minute

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: A long silence followed.
children.prevalue: A long silence followed

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: So then, Axel, replied the Professor ironically, you have found no courage or energy in these few drops of water?
children.prevalue: So then Axel replied the Professor ironically you have found no courage or energy in these few drops of water

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Courage?
children.prevalue: Courage

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I see you just as feeble-minded as you were before, and still expressing only despair!
children.prevalue: I see you just as feeble minded as you were before and still expressing only despair

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: What sort of a man was this I had to do with, and what schemes was he now revolving in his fearless mind?
children.prevalue: What sort of a man was this I had to do with and what schemes was he now revolving in his fearless mind

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: What! you won't go back?
children.prevalue: What you won t go back

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Should I renounce this expedition just when we have the fairest chance of success! Never!
children.prevalue: Should I renounce this expedition just when we have the fairest chance of success Never

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Then must we resign ourselves to destruction?
children.prevalue: Then must we resign ourselves to destruction

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: No, Axel, no; go back. Hans will go with you. Leave me to myself!
children.prevalue: No Axel no go back Hans will go with you Leave me to myself

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Leave you here!
children.prevalue: Leave you here

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Leave me, I tell you. I have undertaken this expedition. I will carry it out to the end, and I will not return. Go, Axel, go!
children.prevalue: Leave me I tell you I have undertaken this expedition I will carry it out to the end and I will not return Go Axel go

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: My uncle was in high state of excitement. His voice, which had for a moment been tender and gentle, had now become hard and threatening. He was struggling with gloomy resolutions against impossibilities. I would not leave him in this bottomless abyss, and on the other hand the instinct of self-preservation prompted me to fly.
children.prevalue: My uncle was in high state of excitement His voice which had for a moment been tender and gentle had now become hard and threatening He was struggling with gloomy resolutions against impossibilities I would not leave him in this bottomless abyss and on the other hand the instinct of self preservation prompted me to fly

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The guide watched this scene with his usual phlegmatic unconcern. Yet he understood perfectly well what was going on between his two companions. The gestures themselves were sufficient to show that we were each bent on taking a different road; but Hans seemed to take no part in a question upon which depended his life. He was ready to start at a given signal, or to stay, if his master so willed it.

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: How I wished at this moment I could have made him understand me. My words, my complaints, my sorrow would have had some influence over that frigid nature. Those dangers which our guide could not understand I could have demonstrated and proved to him. Together we might have over-ruled the obstinate Professor; if it were needed, we might perhaps have compelled him to regain the heights of Snæfell.

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I drew near to Hans. I placed my hand upon his. He made no movement. My parted lips sufficiently revealed my sufferings. The Icelander slowly moved his head, and calmly pointing to my uncle said:
children.prevalue: I drew near to Hans I placed my hand upon his He made no movement My parted lips sufficiently revealed my sufferings The Icelander slowly moved his head and calmly pointing to my uncle said

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Master.
children.prevalue: Master

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Master! I shouted; you madman! no, he is not the master of our life; we must fly, we must drag him. Do you hear me? Do you understand?
children.prevalue: Master I shouted you madman no he is not the master of our life we must fly we must drag him Do you hear me Do you understand

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: I had seized Hans by the arm. I wished to oblige him to rise. I strove with him. My uncle interposed.
children.prevalue: I had seized Hans by the arm I wished to oblige him to rise I strove with him My uncle interposed

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Be calm, Axel! you will get nothing from that immovable servant. Therefore, listen to my proposal.
children.prevalue: Be calm Axel you will get nothing from that immovable servant Therefore listen to my proposal

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: I crossed my arms, and confronted my uncle boldly.
children.prevalue: I crossed my arms and confronted my uncle boldly

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The want of water, he said, is the only obstacle in our way. In this eastern gallery made up of lavas, schists, and coal, we have not met with a single particle of moisture. Perhaps we shall be more fortunate if we follow the western tunnel.
children.prevalue: The want of water he said is the only obstacle in our way In this eastern gallery made up of lavas schists and coal we have not met with a single particle of moisture Perhaps we shall be more fortunate if we follow the western tunnel

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I shook my head incredulously.
children.prevalue: I shook my head incredulously

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Hear me to the end, the Professor went on with a firm voice. Whilst you were lying there motionless, I went to examine the conformation of that gallery. It penetrates directly downward, and in a few hours it will bring us to the granite rocks. There we must meet with abundant springs. The nature of the rock assures me of this, and instinct agrees with logic to support my conviction. Now, this is my proposal. When Columbus asked of his ships' crews for three days more to discover a new world, those crews, disheartened and sick as they were, recognised the justice of the claim, and he discovered America. I am the Columbus of this nether world, and I only ask for one more day. If in a single day I have not met with the water that we want, I swear to you we will return to the surface of the earth.

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: In spite of my irritation I was moved with these words, as well as with the violence my uncle was doing to his own wishes in making so hazardous a proposal.
children.prevalue: In spite of my irritation I was moved with these words as well as with the violence my uncle was doing to his own wishes in making so hazardous a proposal

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Well, I said, do as you will, and God reward your superhuman energy. You have now but a few hours to tempt fortune. Let us start!
children.prevalue: Well I said do as you will and God reward your superhuman energy You have now but a few hours to tempt fortune Let us start

children.value: TOTAL FAILURE OF WATER
children.prevalue: TOTAL FAILURE OF WATER

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: This time the descent commenced by the new gallery. Hans walked first as was his custom.
children.prevalue: This time the descent commenced by the new gallery Hans walked first as was his custom

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: We had not gone a hundred yards when the Professor, moving his lantern along the walls, cried:
children.prevalue: We had not gone a hundred yards when the Professor moving his lantern along the walls cried

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Here are primitive rocks. Now we are in the right way. Forward!
children.prevalue: Here are primitive rocks Now we are in the right way Forward

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: When in its early stages the earth was slowly cooling, its contraction gave rise in its crust to disruptions, distortions, fissures, and chasms. The passage through which we were moving was such a fissure, through which at one time granite poured out in a molten state. Its thousands of windings formed an inextricable labyrinth through the primeval mass.

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: As fast as we descended, the succession of beds forming the primitive foundation came out with increasing distinctness. Geologists consider this primitive matter to be the base of the mineral crust of the earth, and have ascertained it to be composed of three different formations, schist, gneiss, and mica schist, resting upon that unchangeable foundation, the granite.

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Never had mineralogists found themselves in so marvellous a situation to study nature in situ. What the boring machine, an insensible, inert instrument, was unable to bring to the surface of the inner structure of the globe, we were able to peruse with our own eyes and handle with our own hands.
children.prevalue: Never had mineralogists found themselves in so marvellous a situation to study nature in situ What the boring machine an insensible inert instrument was unable to bring to the surface of the inner structure of the globe we were able to peruse with our own eyes and handle with our own hands

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Through the beds of schist, coloured with delicate shades of green, ran in winding course threads of copper and manganese, with traces of platinum and gold. I thought, what riches are here buried at an unapproachable depth in the earth, hidden for ever from the covetous eyes of the human race! These treasures have been buried at such a profound depth by the convulsions of primeval times that they run no chance of ever being molested by the pickaxe or the spade.
children.prevalue: Through the beds of schist coloured with delicate shades of green ran in winding course threads of copper and manganese with traces of platinum and gold I thought what riches are here buried at an unapproachable depth in the earth hidden for ever from the covetous eyes of the human race These treasures have been buried at such a profound depth by the convulsions of primeval times that they run no chance of ever being molested by the pickaxe or the spade

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: To the schists succeeded gneiss, partially stratified, remarkable for the parallelism and regularity of its lamina, then mica schists, laid in large plates or flakes, revealing their lamellated structure by the sparkle of the white shining mica.
children.prevalue: To the schists succeeded gneiss partially stratified remarkable for the parallelism and regularity of its lamina then mica schists laid in large plates or flakes revealing their lamellated structure by the sparkle of the white shining mica

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The light from our apparatus, reflected from the small facets of quartz, shot sparkling rays at every angle, and I seemed to be moving through a diamond, within which the quickly darting rays broke across each other in a thousand flashing coruscations.
children.prevalue: The light from our apparatus reflected from the small facets of quartz shot sparkling rays at every angle and I seemed to be moving through a diamond within which the quickly darting rays broke across each other in a thousand flashing coruscations

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: About six o'clock this brilliant fete of illuminations underwent a sensible abatement of splendour, then almost ceased. The walls assumed a crystallised though sombre appearance; mica was more closely mingled with the feldspar and quartz to form the proper rocky foundations of the earth, which bears without distortion or crushing the weight of the four terrestrial systems. We were immured within prison walls of granite.

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: It was eight in the evening. No signs of water had yet appeared. I was suffering horribly. My uncle strode on. He refused to stop. He was listening anxiously for the murmur of distant springs. But, no, there was dead silence.
children.prevalue: It was eight in the evening No signs of water had yet appeared I was suffering horribly My uncle strode on He refused to stop He was listening anxiously for the murmur of distant springs But no there was dead silence

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And now my limbs were failing beneath me. I resisted pain and torture, that I might not stop my uncle, which would have driven him to despair, for the day was drawing near to its end, and it was his last.
children.prevalue: And now my limbs were failing beneath me I resisted pain and torture that I might not stop my uncle which would have driven him to despair for the day was drawing near to its end and it was his last

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: At last I failed utterly; I uttered a cry and fell.
children.prevalue: At last I failed utterly I uttered a cry and fell

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Come to me, I am dying.
children.prevalue: Come to me I am dying

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: My uncle retraced his steps. He gazed upon me with his arms crossed; then these muttered words passed his lips:
children.prevalue: My uncle retraced his steps He gazed upon me with his arms crossed then these muttered words passed his lips

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: It's all over!
children.prevalue: It s all over

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: The last thing I saw was a fearful gesture of rage, and my eyes closed.
children.prevalue: The last thing I saw was a fearful gesture of rage and my eyes closed

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: When I reopened them I saw my two companions motionless and rolled up in their coverings. Were they asleep? As for me, I could not get one moment's sleep. I was suffering too keenly, and what embittered my thoughts was that there was no remedy. My uncle's last words echoed painfully in my ears: it's all over! For in such a fearful state of debility it was madness to think of ever reaching the upper world again.

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: We had above us a league and a half of terrestrial crust. The weight of it seemed to be crushing down upon my shoulders. I felt weighed down, and I exhausted myself with imaginary violent exertions to turn round upon my granite couch.
children.prevalue: We had above us a league and a half of terrestrial crust The weight of it seemed to be crushing down upon my shoulders I felt weighed down and I exhausted myself with imaginary violent exertions to turn round upon my granite couch

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: A few hours passed away. A deep silence reigned around us, the silence of the grave. No sound could reach us through walls, the thinnest of which were five miles thick.
children.prevalue: A few hours passed away A deep silence reigned around us the silence of the grave No sound could reach us through walls the thinnest of which were five miles thick

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Yet in the midst of my stupefaction I seemed to be aware of a noise. It was dark down the tunnel, but I seemed to see the Icelander vanishing from our sight with the lamp in his hand.
children.prevalue: Yet in the midst of my stupefaction I seemed to be aware of a noise It was dark down the tunnel but I seemed to see the Icelander vanishing from our sight with the lamp in his hand

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Why was he leaving us? Was Hans going to forsake us? My uncle was fast asleep. I wanted to shout, but my voice died upon my parched and swollen lips. The darkness became deeper, and the last sound died away in the far distance.
children.prevalue: Why was he leaving us Was Hans going to forsake us My uncle was fast asleep I wanted to shout but my voice died upon my parched and swollen lips The darkness became deeper and the last sound died away in the far distance

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Hans has abandoned us, I cried. Hans! Hans!
children.prevalue: Hans has abandoned us I cried Hans Hans

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: But these words were only spoken within me. They went no farther. Yet after the first moment of terror I felt ashamed of suspecting a man of such extraordinary faithfulness. Instead of ascending he was descending the gallery. An evil design would have taken him up not down. This reflection restored me to calmness, and I turned to other thoughts. None but some weighty motive could have induced so quiet a man to forfeit his sleep. Was he on a journey of discovery? Had he during the silence of the night caught a sound, a murmuring of something in the distance, which had failed to affect my hearing?
children.prevalue: But these words were only spoken within me They went no farther Yet after the first moment of terror I felt ashamed of suspecting a man of such extraordinary faithfulness Instead of ascending he was descending the gallery An evil design would have taken him up not down This reflection restored me to calmness and I turned to other thoughts None but some weighty motive could have induced so quiet a man to forfeit his sleep Was he on a journey of discovery Had he during the silence of the night caught a sound a murmuring of something in the distance which had failed to affect my hearing

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: WATER DISCOVERED
children.prevalue: WATER DISCOVERED

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: For a whole hour I was trying to work out in my delirious brain the reasons which might have influenced this seemingly tranquil huntsman. The absurdest notions ran in utter confusion through my mind. I thought madness was coming on!
children.prevalue: For a whole hour I was trying to work out in my delirious brain the reasons which might have influenced this seemingly tranquil huntsman The absurdest notions ran in utter confusion through my mind I thought madness was coming on

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: But at last a noise of footsteps was heard in the dark abyss. Hans was approaching. A flickering light was beginning to glimmer on the wall of our darksome prison; then it came out full at the mouth of the gallery. Hans appeared.
children.prevalue: But at last a noise of footsteps was heard in the dark abyss Hans was approaching A flickering light was beginning to glimmer on the wall of our darksome prison then it came out full at the mouth of the gallery Hans appeared

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: He drew close to my uncle, laid his hand upon his shoulder, and gently woke him. My uncle rose up.
children.prevalue: He drew close to my uncle laid his hand upon his shoulder and gently woke him My uncle rose up

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: What is the matter? he asked.
children.prevalue: What is the matter he asked

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: _Watten!_ replied the huntsman.
children.prevalue: Watten replied the huntsman

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: No doubt under the inspiration of intense pain everybody becomes endowed with the gift of divers tongues. I did not know a word of Danish, yet instinctively I understood the word he had uttered.
children.prevalue: No doubt under the inspiration of intense pain everybody becomes endowed with the gift of divers tongues I did not know a word of Danish yet instinctively I understood the word he had uttered

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Water! water! I cried, clapping my hands and gesticulating like a madman.
children.prevalue: Water water I cried clapping my hands and gesticulating like a madman

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Water! repeated my uncle. Hvar? he asked, in Icelandic.
children.prevalue: Water repeated my uncle Hvar he asked in Icelandic

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: _Nedat,_ replied Hans.
children.prevalue: Nedat replied Hans

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Where? Down below! I understood it all. I seized the hunter's hands, and pressed them while he looked on me without moving a muscle of his countenance.
children.prevalue: Where Down below I understood it all I seized the hunter s hands and pressed them while he looked on me without moving a muscle of his countenance

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The preparations for our departure were not long in making, and we were soon on our way down a passage inclining two feet in seven. In an hour we had gone a mile and a quarter, and descended two thousand feet.
children.prevalue: The preparations for our departure were not long in making and we were soon on our way down a passage inclining two feet in seven In an hour we had gone a mile and a quarter and descended two thousand feet

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Then I began to hear distinctly quite a new sound of something running within the thickness of the granite wall, a kind of dull, dead rumbling, like distant thunder. During the first part of our walk, not meeting with the promised spring, I felt my agony returning; but then my uncle acquainted me with the cause of the strange noise.
children.prevalue: Then I began to hear distinctly quite a new sound of something running within the thickness of the granite wall a kind of dull dead rumbling like distant thunder During the first part of our walk not meeting with the promised spring I felt my agony returning but then my uncle acquainted me with the cause of the strange noise

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Hans was not mistaken, he said. What you hear is the rushing of a torrent.
children.prevalue: Hans was not mistaken he said What you hear is the rushing of a torrent

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: A torrent? I exclaimed.
children.prevalue: A torrent I exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: There can be no doubt; a subterranean river is flowing around us.
children.prevalue: There can be no doubt a subterranean river is flowing around us

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: We hurried forward in the greatest excitement. I was no longer sensible of my fatigue. This murmuring of waters close at hand was already refreshing me. It was audibly increasing. The torrent, after having for some time flowed over our heads, was now running within the left wall, roaring and rushing. Frequently I touched the wall, hoping to feel some indications of moisture: But there was no hope here.

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Yet another half hour, another half league was passed.
children.prevalue: Yet another half hour another half league was passed

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Then it became clear that the hunter had gone no farther. Guided by an instinct peculiar to mountaineers he had as it were felt this torrent through the rock; but he had certainly seen none of the precious liquid; he had drunk nothing himself.
children.prevalue: Then it became clear that the hunter had gone no farther Guided by an instinct peculiar to mountaineers he had as it were felt this torrent through the rock but he had certainly seen none of the precious liquid he had drunk nothing himself

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Soon it became evident that if we continued our walk we should widen the distance between ourselves and the stream, the noise of which was becoming fainter.
children.prevalue: Soon it became evident that if we continued our walk we should widen the distance between ourselves and the stream the noise of which was becoming fainter

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: We returned. Hans stopped where the torrent seemed closest. I sat near the wall, while the waters were flowing past me at a distance of two feet with extreme violence. But there was a thick granite wall between us and the object of our desires.
children.prevalue: We returned Hans stopped where the torrent seemed closest I sat near the wall while the waters were flowing past me at a distance of two feet with extreme violence But there was a thick granite wall between us and the object of our desires

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Without reflection, without asking if there were any means of procuring the water, I gave way to a movement of despair.
children.prevalue: Without reflection without asking if there were any means of procuring the water I gave way to a movement of despair

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Hans glanced at me with, I thought, a smile of compassion.
children.prevalue: Hans glanced at me with I thought a smile of compassion

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: He rose and took the lamp. I followed him. He moved towards the wall. I looked on. He applied his ear against the dry stone, and moved it slowly to and fro, listening intently. I perceived at once that he was examining to find the exact place where the torrent could be heard the loudest. He met with that point on the left side of the tunnel, at three feet from the ground.
children.prevalue: He rose and took the lamp I followed him He moved towards the wall I looked on He applied his ear against the dry stone and moved it slowly to and fro listening intently I perceived at once that he was examining to find the exact place where the torrent could be heard the loudest He met with that point on the left side of the tunnel at three feet from the ground

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I was stirred up with excitement. I hardly dared guess what the hunter was about to do. But I could not but understand, and applaud and cheer him on, when I saw him lay hold of the pickaxe to make an attack upon the rock.
children.prevalue: I was stirred up with excitement I hardly dared guess what the hunter was about to do But I could not but understand and applaud and cheer him on when I saw him lay hold of the pickaxe to make an attack upon the rock

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: We are saved! I cried.
children.prevalue: We are saved I cried

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Yes, cried my uncle, almost frantic with excitement. Hans is right. Capital fellow! Who but he would have thought of it?
children.prevalue: Yes cried my uncle almost frantic with excitement Hans is right Capital fellow Who but he would have thought of it

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Yes; who but he? Such an expedient, however simple, would never have entered into our minds. True, it seemed most hazardous to strike a blow of the hammer in this part of the earth's structure. Suppose some displacement should occur and crush us all! Suppose the torrent, bursting through, should drown us in a sudden flood! There was nothing vain in these fancies. But still no fears of falling rocks or rushing floods could stay us now; and our thirst was so intense that, to satisfy it, we would have dared the waves of the north Atlantic.
children.prevalue: Yes who but he Such an expedient however simple would never have entered into our minds True it seemed most hazardous to strike a blow of the hammer in this part of the earth s structure Suppose some displacement should occur and crush us all Suppose the torrent bursting through should drown us in a sudden flood There was nothing vain in these fancies But still no fears of falling rocks or rushing floods could stay us now and our thirst was so intense that to satisfy it we would have dared the waves of the north Atlantic

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Hans set about the task which my uncle and I together could not have accomplished. If our impatience had armed our hands with power, we should have shattered the rock into a thousand fragments. Not so Hans. Full of self possession, he calmly wore his way through the rock with a steady succession of light and skilful strokes, working through an aperture six inches wide at the outside. I could hear a louder noise of flowing waters, and I fancied I could feel the delicious fluid refreshing my parched lips.
children.prevalue: Hans set about the task which my uncle and I together could not have accomplished If our impatience had armed our hands with power we should have shattered the rock into a thousand fragments Not so Hans Full of self possession he calmly wore his way through the rock with a steady succession of light and skilful strokes working through an aperture six inches wide at the outside I could hear a louder noise of flowing waters and I fancied I could feel the delicious fluid refreshing my parched lips

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The pick had soon penetrated two feet into the granite partition, and our man had worked for above an hour. I was in an agony of impatience. My uncle wanted to employ stronger measures, and I had some difficulty in dissuading him; still he had just taken a pickaxe in his hand, when a sudden hissing was heard, and a jet of water spurted out with violence against the opposite wall.
children.prevalue: The pick had soon penetrated two feet into the granite partition and our man had worked for above an hour I was in an agony of impatience My uncle wanted to employ stronger measures and I had some difficulty in dissuading him still he had just taken a pickaxe in his hand when a sudden hissing was heard and a jet of water spurted out with violence against the opposite wall

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Hans, almost thrown off his feet by the violence of the shock, uttered a cry of grief and disappointment, of which I soon under-. stood the cause, when plunging my hands into the spouting torrent, I withdrew them in haste, for the water was scalding hot.
children.prevalue: Hans almost thrown off his feet by the violence of the shock uttered a cry of grief and disappointment of which I soon under stood the cause when plunging my hands into the spouting torrent I withdrew them in haste for the water was scalding hot

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The water is at the boiling point, I cried.
children.prevalue: The water is at the boiling point I cried

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Well, never mind, let it cool, my uncle replied.
children.prevalue: Well never mind let it cool my uncle replied

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The tunnel was filling with steam, whilst a stream was forming, which by degrees wandered away into subterranean windings, and soon we had the satisfaction of swallowing our first draught.
children.prevalue: The tunnel was filling with steam whilst a stream was forming which by degrees wandered away into subterranean windings and soon we had the satisfaction of swallowing our first draught

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Could anything be more delicious than the sensation that our burning intolerable thirst was passing away, and leaving us to enjoy comfort and pleasure? But where was this water from? No matter. It was water; and though still warm, it brought life back to the dying. I kept drinking without stopping, and almost without tasting.
children.prevalue: Could anything be more delicious than the sensation that our burning intolerable thirst was passing away and leaving us to enjoy comfort and pleasure But where was this water from No matter It was water and though still warm it brought life back to the dying I kept drinking without stopping and almost without tasting

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: At last after a most delightful time of reviving energy, I cried, Why, this is a chalybeate spring!
children.prevalue: At last after a most delightful time of reviving energy I cried Why this is a chalybeate spring

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Nothing could be better for the digestion, said my uncle. It is highly impregnated with iron. It will be as good for us as going to the Spa, or to Töplitz.
children.prevalue: Nothing could be better for the digestion said my uncle It is highly impregnated with iron It will be as good for us as going to the Spa or to Töplitz

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Well, it is delicious!
children.prevalue: Well it is delicious

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Of course it is, water should be, found six miles underground. It has an inky flavour, which is not at all unpleasant. What a capital source of strength Hans has found for us here. We will call it after his name.
children.prevalue: Of course it is water should be found six miles underground It has an inky flavour which is not at all unpleasant What a capital source of strength Hans has found for us here We will call it after his name

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Agreed, I cried.
children.prevalue: Agreed I cried

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: And Hansbach it was from that moment.
children.prevalue: And Hansbach it was from that moment

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Hans was none the prouder. After a moderate draught, he went quietly into a corner to rest.
children.prevalue: Hans was none the prouder After a moderate draught he went quietly into a corner to rest

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Now, I said, we must not lose this water.
children.prevalue: Now I said we must not lose this water

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: What is the use of troubling ourselves? my uncle, replied. I fancy it will never fail.
children.prevalue: What is the use of troubling ourselves my uncle replied I fancy it will never fail

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Never mind, we cannot be sure; let us fill the water bottle and our flasks, and then stop up the opening.
children.prevalue: Never mind we cannot be sure let us fill the water bottle and our flasks and then stop up the opening

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: My advice was followed so far as getting in a supply; but the stopping up of the hole was not so easy to accomplish. It was in vain that we took up fragments of granite, and stuffed them in with tow, we only scalded our hands without succeeding. The pressure was too great, and our efforts were fruitless.
children.prevalue: My advice was followed so far as getting in a supply but the stopping up of the hole was not so easy to accomplish It was in vain that we took up fragments of granite and stuffed them in with tow we only scalded our hands without succeeding The pressure was too great and our efforts were fruitless

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: It is quite plain, said I, that the higher body of this water is at a considerable elevation. The force of the jet shows that.
children.prevalue: It is quite plain said I that the higher body of this water is at a considerable elevation The force of the jet shows that

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: No doubt, answered my uncle. If this column of water is 32,000 feet high--that is, from the surface of the earth, it is equal to the weight of a thousand atmospheres. But I have got an idea.
children.prevalue: No doubt answered my uncle If this column of water is 32 000 feet high that is from the surface of the earth it is equal to the weight of a thousand atmospheres But I have got an idea

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Why should we trouble ourselves to stop the stream from coming out at all?
children.prevalue: Why should we trouble ourselves to stop the stream from coming out at all

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Because-- Well, I could not assign a reason.
children.prevalue: Because Well I could not assign a reason

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: When our flasks are empty, where shall we fill them again? Can we tell that?
children.prevalue: When our flasks are empty where shall we fill them again Can we tell that

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: No; there was no certainty.
children.prevalue: No there was no certainty

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Well, let us allow the water to run on. It will flow down, and will both guide and refresh us.
children.prevalue: Well let us allow the water to run on It will flow down and will both guide and refresh us

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: That is well planned, I cried. With this stream for our guide, there is no reason why we should not succeed in our undertaking.
children.prevalue: That is well planned I cried With this stream for our guide there is no reason why we should not succeed in our undertaking

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Ah, my boy! you agree with me now, cried the Professor, laughing.
children.prevalue: Ah my boy you agree with me now cried the Professor laughing

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: I agree with you most heartily.
children.prevalue: I agree with you most heartily

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Well, let us rest awhile; and then we will start again.
children.prevalue: Well let us rest awhile and then we will start again

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: I was forgetting that it was night. The chronometer soon informed me of that fact; and in a very short time, refreshed and thankful, we all three fell into a sound sleep.
children.prevalue: I was forgetting that it was night The chronometer soon informed me of that fact and in a very short time refreshed and thankful we all three fell into a sound sleep

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: WELL SAID, OLD MOLE! CANST THOU WORK I' THE GROUND SO FAST?
children.prevalue: WELL SAID OLD MOLE CANST THOU WORK I THE GROUND SO FAST

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: By the next day we had forgotten all our sufferings. At first, I was wondering that I was no longer thirsty, and I was for asking for the reason. The answer came in the murmuring of the stream at my feet.
children.prevalue: By the next day we had forgotten all our sufferings At first I was wondering that I was no longer thirsty and I was for asking for the reason The answer came in the murmuring of the stream at my feet

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: We breakfasted, and drank of this excellent chalybeate water. I felt wonderfully stronger, and quite decided upon pushing on. Why should not so firmly convinced a man as my uncle, furnished with so industrious a guide as Hans, and accompanied by so determined a nephew as myself, go on to final success? Such were the magnificent plans which struggled for mastery within me. If it had been proposed to me to return to the summit of Snæfell, I should have indignantly declined.
children.prevalue: We breakfasted and drank of this excellent chalybeate water I felt wonderfully stronger and quite decided upon pushing on Why should not so firmly convinced a man as my uncle furnished with so industrious a guide as Hans and accompanied by so determined a nephew as myself go on to final success Such were the magnificent plans which struggled for mastery within me If it had been proposed to me to return to the summit of Snæfell I should have indignantly declined

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Most fortunately, all we had to do was to descend.
children.prevalue: Most fortunately all we had to do was to descend

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Let us start! I cried, awakening by my shouts the echoes of the vaulted hollows of the earth.
children.prevalue: Let us start I cried awakening by my shouts the echoes of the vaulted hollows of the earth

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: On Thursday, at 8 a.m., we started afresh. The granite tunnel winding from side to side, earned us past unexpected turns, and seemed almost to form a labyrinth; but, on the whole, its direction seemed to be south-easterly. My uncle never ceased to consult his compass, to keep account of the ground gone over.

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The gallery dipped down a very little way from the horizontal, scarcely more than two inches in a fathom, and the stream ran gently murmuring at our feet. I compared it to a friendly genius guiding us underground, and caressed with my hand the soft naiad, whose comforting voice accompanied our steps. With my reviving spirits these mythological notions seemed to come unbidden.

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: As for my uncle, he was beginning to storm against the horizontal road. He loved nothing better than a vertical path; but this way seemed indefinitely prolonged, and instead of sliding along the hypothenuse as we were now doing, he would willingly have dropped down the terrestrial radius. But there was no help for it, and as long as we were approaching the centre at all we felt that we must not complain.

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: From time to time, a steeper path appeared; our naiad then began to tumble before us with a hoarser murmur, and we went down with her to a greater depth.
children.prevalue: From time to time a steeper path appeared our naiad then began to tumble before us with a hoarser murmur and we went down with her to a greater depth

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: On the whole, that day and the next we made considerable way horizontally, very little vertically.
children.prevalue: On the whole that day and the next we made considerable way horizontally very little vertically

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: On Friday evening, the 10th of July, according to our calculations, we were thirty leagues south-east of Rejkiavik, and at a depth of two leagues and a half.
children.prevalue: On Friday evening the 10th of July according to our calculations we were thirty leagues south east of Rejkiavik and at a depth of two leagues and a half

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: At our feet there now opened a frightful abyss. My uncle, however, was not to be daunted, and he clapped his hands at the steepness of the descent.
children.prevalue: At our feet there now opened a frightful abyss My uncle however was not to be daunted and he clapped his hands at the steepness of the descent

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: This will take us a long way, he cried, and without much difficulty; for the projections in the rock form quite a staircase.
children.prevalue: This will take us a long way he cried and without much difficulty for the projections in the rock form quite a staircase

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The ropes were so fastened by Hans as to guard against accident, and the descent commenced. I can hardly call it perilous, for I was beginning to be familiar with this kind of exercise.
children.prevalue: The ropes were so fastened by Hans as to guard against accident and the descent commenced I can hardly call it perilous for I was beginning to be familiar with this kind of exercise

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: This well, or abyss, was a narrow cleft in the mass of the granite, called by geologists a 'fault,' and caused by the unequal cooling of the globe of the earth. If it had at one time been a passage for eruptive matter thrown out by Snæfell, I still could not understand why no trace was left of its passage. We kept going down a kind of winding staircase, which seemed almost to have been made by the hand of man.

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Every quarter of an hour we were obliged to halt, to take a little necessary repose and restore the action of our limbs. We then sat down upon a fragment of rock, and we talked as we ate and drank from the stream.
children.prevalue: Every quarter of an hour we were obliged to halt to take a little necessary repose and restore the action of our limbs We then sat down upon a fragment of rock and we talked as we ate and drank from the stream

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Of course, down this fault the Hansbach fell in a cascade, and lost some of its volume; but there was enough and to spare to slake our thirst. Besides, when the incline became more gentle, it would of course resume its peaceable course. At this moment it reminded me of my worthy uncle, in his frequent fits of impatience and anger, while below it ran with the calmness of the Icelandic hunter.

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: On the 6th and 7th of July we kept following the spiral curves of this singular well, penetrating in actual distance no more than two leagues; but being carried to a depth of five leagues below the level of the sea. But on the 8th, about noon, the fault took, towards the south-east, a much gentler slope, one of about forty-five degrees.

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Then the road became monotonously easy. It could not be otherwise, for there was no landscape to vary the stages of our journey.
children.prevalue: Then the road became monotonously easy It could not be otherwise for there was no landscape to vary the stages of our journey

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: On Wednesday, the 15th, we were seven leagues underground, and had travelled fifty leagues away from Snæfell. Although we were tired, our health was perfect, and the medicine chest had not yet had occasion to be opened.
children.prevalue: On Wednesday the 15th we were seven leagues underground and had travelled fifty leagues away from Snæfell Although we were tired our health was perfect and the medicine chest had not yet had occasion to be opened

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: My uncle noted every hour the indications of the compass, the chronometer, the aneroid, and the thermometer the very same which he has published in his scientific report of our journey. It was therefore not difficult to know exactly our whereabouts. When he told me that we had gone fifty leagues horizontally, I could not repress an exclamation of astonishment, at the thought that we had now long left Iceland behind us.

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: What is the matter? he cried.
children.prevalue: What is the matter he cried

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I was reflecting that if your calculations are correct we are no longer under Iceland.
children.prevalue: I was reflecting that if your calculations are correct we are no longer under Iceland

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Do you think so?
children.prevalue: Do you think so

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I am not mistaken, I said, and examining the map, I added, We have passed Cape Portland, and those fifty leagues bring us under the wide expanse of ocean.
children.prevalue: I am not mistaken I said and examining the map I added We have passed Cape Portland and those fifty leagues bring us under the wide expanse of ocean

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Under the sea, my uncle repeated, rubbing his hands with delight.
children.prevalue: Under the sea my uncle repeated rubbing his hands with delight

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Can it be? I said. Is the ocean spread above our heads?
children.prevalue: Can it be I said Is the ocean spread above our heads

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Of course, Axel. What can be more natural? At Newcastle are there not coal mines extending far under the sea?
children.prevalue: Of course Axel What can be more natural At Newcastle are there not coal mines extending far under the sea

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: It was all very well for the Professor to call this so simple, but I could not feel quite easy at the thought that the boundless ocean was rolling over my head. And yet it really mattered very little whether it was the plains and mountains that covered our heads, or the Atlantic waves, as long as we were arched over by solid granite. And, besides, I was getting used to this idea; for the tunnel, now running straight, now winding as capriciously in its inclines as in its turnings, but constantly preserving its south-easterly direction, and always running deeper, was gradually carrying us to very great depths indeed.

children.value: Four days later, Saturday, the 18th of July, in the evening, we arrived at a kind of vast grotto; and here my uncle paid Hans his weekly wages, and it was settled that the next day, Sunday, should be a day of rest.
