children.value: I therefore awoke next day relieved from the preoccupation of an immediate start. Although we were in the very deepest of known depths, there was something not unpleasant about it. And, besides, we were beginning to get accustomed to this troglodyte [1] life. I no longer thought of sun, moon, and stars, trees, houses, and towns, nor of any of those terrestrial superfluities which are necessaries of men who live upon the earth's surface. Being fossils, we looked upon all those things as mere jokes.

But would this state of things last in the strange place we had come to? Perhaps it might.

children.value: For several days steeper inclines, some even frightfully near to the perpendicular, brought us deeper and deeper into the mass of the interior of the earth. Some days we advanced nearer to the centre by a league and a half, or nearly two leagues. These were perilous descents, in which the skill and marvellous coolness of Hans were invaluable to us. That unimpassioned Icelander devoted himself with incomprehensible deliberation; and, thanks to him, we crossed many a dangerous spot which we should never have cleared alone.

children.prevalue: Suddenly turning round I observed that I was alone

children.name: Paragraph_17

children.name: Paragraph_5

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I tried to carry back my ideas to things on the surface of the earth. I could scarcely succeed. Hamburg, the house in the Königstrasse, my poor Gräuben, all that busy world underneath which I was wandering about, was passing in rapid confusion before my terrified memory. I could revive with vivid reality all the incidents of our voyage, Iceland, M. Fridrikssen, Snæfell. I said to myself that if, in such a position as I was now in, I was fool enough to cling to one glimpse of hope, it would be madness, and that the best thing I could do was to despair.
children.prevalue: I tried to carry back my ideas to things on the surface of the earth I could scarcely succeed Hamburg the house in the Königstrasse my poor Gräuben all that busy world underneath which I was wandering about was passing in rapid confusion before my terrified memory I could revive with vivid reality all the incidents of our voyage Iceland M Fridrikssen Snæfell I said to myself that if in such a position as I was now in I was fool enough to cling to one glimpse of hope it would be madness and that the best thing I could do was to despair

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: What human power could restore me to the light of the sun by rending asunder the huge arches of rock which united over my head, buttressing each other with impregnable strength? Who could place my feet on the right path, and bring me back to my company?
children.prevalue: What human power could restore me to the light of the sun by rending asunder the huge arches of rock which united over my head buttressing each other with impregnable strength Who could place my feet on the right path and bring me back to my company

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Oh, my uncle! burst from my lips in the tone of despair.
children.prevalue: Oh my uncle burst from my lips in the tone of despair

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: It was my only word of reproach, for I knew how much he must be suffering in seeking me, wherever he might be.
children.prevalue: It was my only word of reproach for I knew how much he must be suffering in seeking me wherever he might be

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: When I saw myself thus far removed from all earthly help I had recourse to heavenly succour. The remembrance of my childhood, the recollection of my mother, whom I had only known in my tender early years, came back to me, and I knelt in prayer imploring for the Divine help of which I was so little worthy.
children.prevalue: When I saw myself thus far removed from all earthly help I had recourse to heavenly succour The remembrance of my childhood the recollection of my mother whom I had only known in my tender early years came back to me and I knelt in prayer imploring for the Divine help of which I was so little worthy

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: This return of trust in God's providence allayed the turbulence of my fears, and I was enabled to concentrate upon my situation all the force of my intelligence.
children.prevalue: This return of trust in God s providence allayed the turbulence of my fears and I was enabled to concentrate upon my situation all the force of my intelligence

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I had three days' provisions with me and my flask was full. But I could not remain alone for long. Should I go up or down?
children.prevalue: I had three days provisions with me and my flask was full But I could not remain alone for long Should I go up or down

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Up, of course; up continually.
children.prevalue: Up of course up continually

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I must thus arrive at the point where I had left the stream, that fatal turn in the road. With the stream at my feet, I might hope to regain the summit of Snæfell.
children.prevalue: I must thus arrive at the point where I had left the stream that fatal turn in the road With the stream at my feet I might hope to regain the summit of Snæfell

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Why had I not thought of that sooner? Here was evidently a chance of safety. The most pressing duty was to find out again the course of the Hansbach. I rose, and leaning upon my iron-pointed stick I ascended the gallery. The slope was rather steep. I walked on without hope but without indecision, like a man who has made up his mind.
children.prevalue: Why had I not thought of that sooner Here was evidently a chance of safety The most pressing duty was to find out again the course of the Hansbach I rose and leaning upon my iron pointed stick I ascended the gallery The slope was rather steep I walked on without hope but without indecision like a man who has made up his mind

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: For half an hour I met with no obstacle. I tried to recognise my way by the form of the tunnel, by the projections of certain rocks, by the disposition of the fractures. But no particular sign appeared, and I soon saw that this gallery could not bring me back to the turning point. It came to an abrupt end. I struck against an impenetrable wall, and fell down upon the rock.
children.prevalue: For half an hour I met with no obstacle I tried to recognise my way by the form of the tunnel by the projections of certain rocks by the disposition of the fractures But no particular sign appeared and I soon saw that this gallery could not bring me back to the turning point It came to an abrupt end I struck against an impenetrable wall and fell down upon the rock

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Unspeakable despair then seized upon me. I lay overwhelmed, aghast! My last hope was shattered against this granite wall.
children.prevalue: Unspeakable despair then seized upon me I lay overwhelmed aghast My last hope was shattered against this granite wall

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Lost in this labyrinth, whose windings crossed each other in all directions, it was no use to think of flight any longer. Here I must die the most dreadful of deaths. And, strange to say, the thought came across me that when some day my petrified remains should be found thirty leagues below the surface in the bowels of the earth, the discovery might lead to grave scientific discussions.
children.prevalue: Lost in this labyrinth whose windings crossed each other in all directions it was no use to think of flight any longer Here I must die the most dreadful of deaths And strange to say the thought came across me that when some day my petrified remains should be found thirty leagues below the surface in the bowels of the earth the discovery might lead to grave scientific discussions

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: I tried to speak aloud, but hoarse sounds alone passed my dry lips. I panted for breath.
children.prevalue: I tried to speak aloud but hoarse sounds alone passed my dry lips I panted for breath

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: In the midst of my agony a new terror laid hold of me. In falling my lamp had got wrong. I could not set it right, and its light was paling and would soon disappear altogether.
children.prevalue: In the midst of my agony a new terror laid hold of me In falling my lamp had got wrong I could not set it right and its light was paling and would soon disappear altogether

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I gazed painfully upon the luminous current growing weaker and weaker in the wire coil. A dim procession of moving shadows seemed slowly unfolding down the darkening walls. I scarcely dared to shut my eyes for one moment, for fear of losing the least glimmer of this precious light. Every instant it seemed about to vanish and the dense blackness to come rolling in palpably upon me.
children.prevalue: I gazed painfully upon the luminous current growing weaker and weaker in the wire coil A dim procession of moving shadows seemed slowly unfolding down the darkening walls I scarcely dared to shut my eyes for one moment for fear of losing the least glimmer of this precious light Every instant it seemed about to vanish and the dense blackness to come rolling in palpably upon me

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: One last trembling glimmer shot feebly up. I watched it in trembling and anxiety; I drank it in as if I could preserve it, concentrating upon it the full power of my eyes, as upon the very last sensation of light which they were ever to experience, and the next moment I lay in the heavy gloom of deep, thick, unfathomable darkness.
children.prevalue: One last trembling glimmer shot feebly up I watched it in trembling and anxiety I drank it in as if I could preserve it concentrating upon it the full power of my eyes as upon the very last sensation of light which they were ever to experience and the next moment I lay in the heavy gloom of deep thick unfathomable darkness

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: A terrible cry of anguish burst from me. Upon earth, in the midst of the darkest night, light never abdicates its functions altogether. It is still subtle and diffusive, but whatever little there may be, the eye still catches that little. Here there was not an atom; the total darkness made me totally blind.
children.prevalue: A terrible cry of anguish burst from me Upon earth in the midst of the darkest night light never abdicates its functions altogether It is still subtle and diffusive but whatever little there may be the eye still catches that little Here there was not an atom the total darkness made me totally blind

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Then I began to lose my head. I arose with my arms stretched out before me, attempting painfully to feel my way. I began to run wildly, hurrying through the inextricable maze, still descending, still running through the substance of the earth's thick crust, a struggling denizen of geological 'faults,' crying, shouting, yelling, soon bruised by contact with the jagged rock, falling and rising again bleeding, trying to drink the blood which covered my face, and even waiting for some rock to shatter my skull against.
children.prevalue: Then I began to lose my head I arose with my arms stretched out before me attempting painfully to feel my way I began to run wildly hurrying through the inextricable maze still descending still running through the substance of the earth s thick crust a struggling denizen of geological faults crying shouting yelling soon bruised by contact with the jagged rock falling and rising again bleeding trying to drink the blood which covered my face and even waiting for some rock to shatter my skull against

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I shall never know whither my mad career took me. After the lapse of some hours, no doubt exhausted, I fell like a lifeless lump at the foot of the wall, and lost all consciousness.
children.prevalue: I shall never know whither my mad career took me After the lapse of some hours no doubt exhausted I fell like a lifeless lump at the foot of the wall and lost all consciousness

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: THE RESCUE IN THE WHISPERING GALLERY
children.prevalue: THE RESCUE IN THE WHISPERING GALLERY

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: When I returned to partial life my face was wet with tears. How long that state of insensibility had lasted I cannot say. I had no means now of taking account of time. Never was solitude equal to this, never had any living being been so utterly forsaken.
children.prevalue: When I returned to partial life my face was wet with tears How long that state of insensibility had lasted I cannot say I had no means now of taking account of time Never was solitude equal to this never had any living being been so utterly forsaken

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: After my fall I had lost a good deal of blood. I felt it flowing over me. Ah! how happy I should have been could I have died, and if death were not yet to be gone through. I would think no longer. I drove away every idea, and, conquered by my grief, I rolled myself to the foot of the opposite wall.
children.prevalue: After my fall I had lost a good deal of blood I felt it flowing over me Ah how happy I should have been could I have died and if death were not yet to be gone through I would think no longer I drove away every idea and conquered by my grief I rolled myself to the foot of the opposite wall

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Already I was feeling the approach of another faint, and was hoping for complete annihilation, when a loud noise reached me. It was like the distant rumble of continuous thunder, and I could hear its sounding undulations rolling far away into the remote recesses of the abyss.
children.prevalue: Already I was feeling the approach of another faint and was hoping for complete annihilation when a loud noise reached me It was like the distant rumble of continuous thunder and I could hear its sounding undulations rolling far away into the remote recesses of the abyss

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Whence could this noise proceed? It must be from some phenomenon proceeding in the great depths amidst which I lay helpless. Was it an explosion of gas? Was it the fall of some mighty pillar of the globe?
children.prevalue: Whence could this noise proceed It must be from some phenomenon proceeding in the great depths amidst which I lay helpless Was it an explosion of gas Was it the fall of some mighty pillar of the globe

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I listened still. I wanted to know if the noise would be repeated. A quarter of an hour passed away. Silence reigned in this gallery. I could not hear even the beating of my heart.
children.prevalue: I listened still I wanted to know if the noise would be repeated A quarter of an hour passed away Silence reigned in this gallery I could not hear even the beating of my heart

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Suddenly my ear, resting by chance against the wall, caught, or seemed to catch, certain vague, indescribable, distant, articulate sounds, as of words.
children.prevalue: Suddenly my ear resting by chance against the wall caught or seemed to catch certain vague indescribable distant articulate sounds as of words

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: This is a delusion, I thought.
children.prevalue: This is a delusion I thought

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: But it was not. Listening more attentively, I heard in reality a murmuring of voices. But my weakness prevented me from understanding what the voices said. Yet it was language, I was sure of it.
children.prevalue: But it was not Listening more attentively I heard in reality a murmuring of voices But my weakness prevented me from understanding what the voices said Yet it was language I was sure of it

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: For a moment I feared the words might be my own, brought back by the echo. Perhaps I had been crying out unknown to myself. I closed my lips firmly, and laid my ear against the wall again.
children.prevalue: For a moment I feared the words might be my own brought back by the echo Perhaps I had been crying out unknown to myself I closed my lips firmly and laid my ear against the wall again

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Yes, truly, some one is speaking; those are words!
children.prevalue: Yes truly some one is speaking those are words

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Even a few feet from the wall I could hear distinctly. I succeeded in catching uncertain, strange, undistinguishable words. They came as if pronounced in low murmured whispers. The word '_forlorad_' was several times repeated in a tone of sympathy and sorrow.
children.prevalue: Even a few feet from the wall I could hear distinctly I succeeded in catching uncertain strange undistinguishable words They came as if pronounced in low murmured whispers The word forlorad was several times repeated in a tone of sympathy and sorrow

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Help! I cried with all my might. Help!
children.prevalue: Help I cried with all my might Help

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I listened, I watched in the darkness for an answer, a cry, a mere breath of sound, but nothing came. Some minutes passed. A whole world of ideas had opened in my mind. I thought that my weakened voice could never penetrate to my companions.
children.prevalue: I listened I watched in the darkness for an answer a cry a mere breath of sound but nothing came Some minutes passed A whole world of ideas had opened in my mind I thought that my weakened voice could never penetrate to my companions

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: It is they, I repeated. What other men can be thirty leagues under ground?
children.prevalue: It is they I repeated What other men can be thirty leagues under ground

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: I again began to listen. Passing my ear over the wall from one place to another, I found the point where the voices seemed to be best heard. The word '_forlorad_' again returned; then the rolling of thunder which had roused me from my lethargy.
children.prevalue: I again began to listen Passing my ear over the wall from one place to another I found the point where the voices seemed to be best heard The word forlorad again returned then the rolling of thunder which had roused me from my lethargy

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: No, I said, no; it is not through such a mass that a voice can be heard. I am surrounded by granite walls, and the loudest explosion could never be heard here! This noise comes along the gallery. There must be here some remarkable exercise of acoustic laws!
children.prevalue: No I said no it is not through such a mass that a voice can be heard I am surrounded by granite walls and the loudest explosion could never be heard here This noise comes along the gallery There must be here some remarkable exercise of acoustic laws

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I listened again, and this time, yes this time, I did distinctly hear my name pronounced across the wide interval.
children.prevalue: I listened again and this time yes this time I did distinctly hear my name pronounced across the wide interval

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: It was my uncle's own voice! He was talking to the guide. And '_forlorad_' is a Danish word.
children.prevalue: It was my uncle s own voice He was talking to the guide And forlorad is a Danish word

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Then I understood it all. To make myself heard, I must speak along this wall, which would conduct the sound of my voice just as wire conducts electricity.
children.prevalue: Then I understood it all To make myself heard I must speak along this wall which would conduct the sound of my voice just as wire conducts electricity

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: But there was no time to lose. If my companions moved but a few steps away, the acoustic phenomenon would cease. I therefore approached the wall, and pronounced these words as clearly as possible:
children.prevalue: But there was no time to lose If my companions moved but a few steps away the acoustic phenomenon would cease I therefore approached the wall and pronounced these words as clearly as possible

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Uncle Liedenbrock!
children.prevalue: Uncle Liedenbrock

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I waited with the deepest anxiety. Sound does not travel with great velocity. Even increased density air has no effect upon its rate of travelling; it merely augments its intensity. Seconds, which seemed ages, passed away, and at last these words reached me:
children.prevalue: I waited with the deepest anxiety Sound does not travel with great velocity Even increased density air has no effect upon its rate of travelling it merely augments its intensity Seconds which seemed ages passed away and at last these words reached me

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Axel! Axel! is it you?
children.prevalue: Axel Axel is it you

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Yes, yes, I replied.
children.prevalue: Yes yes I replied

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: My boy, where are you?
children.prevalue: My boy where are you

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Lost, in the deepest darkness.
children.prevalue: Lost in the deepest darkness

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Where is your lamp?
children.prevalue: Where is your lamp

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: It is out.
children.prevalue: It is out

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: And the stream?
children.prevalue: And the stream

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Disappeared.
children.prevalue: Disappeared

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Axel, Axel, take courage!
children.prevalue: Axel Axel take courage

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Wait! I am exhausted! I can't answer. Speak to me!
children.prevalue: Wait I am exhausted I can t answer Speak to me

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Courage, resumed my uncle. Don't speak. Listen to me. We have looked for you up the gallery and down the gallery. Could not find you. I wept for you, my poor boy. At last, supposing you were still on the Hansbach, we fired our guns. Our voices are audible to each other, but our hands cannot touch. But don't despair, Axel! It is a great thing that we can hear each other.

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: During this time I had been reflecting. A vague hope was returning to my heart. There was one thing I must know to begin with. I placed my lips close to the wall, saying:
children.prevalue: During this time I had been reflecting A vague hope was returning to my heart There was one thing I must know to begin with I placed my lips close to the wall saying

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: My uncle!
children.prevalue: My uncle

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: My boy! came to me after a few seconds.
children.prevalue: My boy came to me after a few seconds

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: We must know how far we are apart.
children.prevalue: We must know how far we are apart

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: That is easy.
children.prevalue: That is easy

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: You have your chronometer?
children.prevalue: You have your chronometer

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Well, take it. Pronounce my name, noting exactly the second when you speak. I will repeat it as soon as it shall come to me, and you will observe the exact moment when you get my answer.
children.prevalue: Well take it Pronounce my name noting exactly the second when you speak I will repeat it as soon as it shall come to me and you will observe the exact moment when you get my answer

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Yes; and half the time between my call and your answer will exactly indicate that which my voice will take in coming to you.
children.prevalue: Yes and half the time between my call and your answer will exactly indicate that which my voice will take in coming to you

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Just so, my uncle.
children.prevalue: Just so my uncle

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Are you ready?
children.prevalue: Are you ready

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Now, attention. I am going to call your name.
children.prevalue: Now attention I am going to call your name

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: I put my ear to the wall, and as soon as the name 'Axel' came I immediately replied Axel, then waited.
children.prevalue: I put my ear to the wall and as soon as the name Axel came I immediately replied Axel then waited

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Forty seconds, said my uncle. Forty seconds between the two words; so the sound takes twenty seconds in coming. Now, at the rate of 1,120 feet in a second, this is 22,400 feet, or four miles and a quarter, nearly.
children.prevalue: Forty seconds said my uncle Forty seconds between the two words so the sound takes twenty seconds in coming Now at the rate of 1 120 feet in a second this is 22 400 feet or four miles and a quarter nearly

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Four miles and a quarter! I murmured.
children.prevalue: Four miles and a quarter I murmured

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: It will soon be over, Axel.
children.prevalue: It will soon be over Axel

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Must I go up or down?
children.prevalue: Must I go up or down

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Down--for this reason: We are in a vast chamber, with endless galleries. Yours must lead into it, for it seems as if all the clefts and fractures of the globe radiated round this vast cavern. So get up, and begin walking. Walk on, drag yourself along, if necessary slide down the steep places, and at the end you will find us ready to receive you. Now begin moving.
children.prevalue: Down for this reason We are in a vast chamber with endless galleries Yours must lead into it for it seems as if all the clefts and fractures of the globe radiated round this vast cavern So get up and begin walking Walk on drag yourself along if necessary slide down the steep places and at the end you will find us ready to receive you Now begin moving

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: These words cheered me up.
children.prevalue: These words cheered me up

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Good bye, uncle. I cried. I am going. There will be no more voices heard when once I have started. So good bye!
children.prevalue: Good bye uncle I cried I am going There will be no more voices heard when once I have started So good bye

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Good bye, Axel, _au revoir!_
children.prevalue: Good bye Axel au revoir

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: These were the last words I heard.
children.prevalue: These were the last words I heard

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: This wonderful underground conversation, carried on with a distance of four miles and a quarter between us, concluded with these words of hope. I thanked God from my heart, for it was He who had conducted me through those vast solitudes to the point where, alone of all others perhaps, the voices of my companions could have reached me.
children.prevalue: This wonderful underground conversation carried on with a distance of four miles and a quarter between us concluded with these words of hope I thanked God from my heart for it was He who had conducted me through those vast solitudes to the point where alone of all others perhaps the voices of my companions could have reached me

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: This acoustic effect is easily explained on scientific grounds. It arose from the concave form of the gallery and the conducting power of the rock. There are many examples of this propagation of sounds which remain unheard in the intermediate space. I remember that a similar phenomenon has been observed in many places; amongst others on the internal surface of the gallery of the dome of St. Paul's in London, and especially in the midst of the curious caverns among the quarries near Syracuse, the most wonderful of which is called Dionysius' Ear.
children.prevalue: This acoustic effect is easily explained on scientific grounds It arose from the concave form of the gallery and the conducting power of the rock There are many examples of this propagation of sounds which remain unheard in the intermediate space I remember that a similar phenomenon has been observed in many places amongst others on the internal surface of the gallery of the dome of St Paul s in London and especially in the midst of the curious caverns among the quarries near Syracuse the most wonderful of which is called Dionysius Ear

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: These remembrances came into my mind, and I clearly saw that since my uncle's voice really reached me, there could be no obstacle between us. Following the direction by which the sound came, of course I should arrive in his presence, if my strength did not fail me.
children.prevalue: These remembrances came into my mind and I clearly saw that since my uncle s voice really reached me there could be no obstacle between us Following the direction by which the sound came of course I should arrive in his presence if my strength did not fail me

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: I therefore rose; I rather dragged myself than walked. The slope was rapid, and I slid down.
children.prevalue: I therefore rose I rather dragged myself than walked The slope was rapid and I slid down

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Soon the swiftness of the descent increased horribly, and threatened to become a fall. I no longer had the strength to stop myself.
children.prevalue: Soon the swiftness of the descent increased horribly and threatened to become a fall I no longer had the strength to stop myself

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Suddenly there was no ground under me. I felt myself revolving in air, striking and rebounding against the craggy projections of a vertical gallery, quite a well; my head struck against a sharp corner of the rock, and I became unconscious.
children.prevalue: Suddenly there was no ground under me I felt myself revolving in air striking and rebounding against the craggy projections of a vertical gallery quite a well my head struck against a sharp corner of the rock and I became unconscious

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: THALATTA! THALATTA!
children.prevalue: THALATTA THALATTA

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: When I came to myself, I was stretched in half darkness, covered with thick coats and blankets. My uncle was watching over me, to discover the least sign of life. At my first sigh he took my hand; when I opened my eyes he uttered a cry of joy.
children.prevalue: When I came to myself I was stretched in half darkness covered with thick coats and blankets My uncle was watching over me to discover the least sign of life At my first sigh he took my hand when I opened my eyes he uttered a cry of joy

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: He lives! he lives! he cried.
children.prevalue: He lives he lives he cried

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Yes, I am still alive, I answered feebly.
children.prevalue: Yes I am still alive I answered feebly

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: My dear nephew, said my uncle, pressing me to his breast, you are saved.
children.prevalue: My dear nephew said my uncle pressing me to his breast you are saved

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I was deeply touched with the tenderness of his manner as he uttered these words, and still more with the care with which he watched over me. But such trials were wanted to bring out the Professor's tenderer qualities.
children.prevalue: I was deeply touched with the tenderness of his manner as he uttered these words and still more with the care with which he watched over me But such trials were wanted to bring out the Professor s tenderer qualities

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: At this moment Hans came, he saw my hand in my uncle's, and I may safely say that there was joy in his countenance.
children.prevalue: At this moment Hans came he saw my hand in my uncle s and I may safely say that there was joy in his countenance

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: _God dag,_ said he.
children.prevalue: God dag said he

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: How do you do, Hans? How are you? And now, uncle, tell me where we are at the present moment?
children.prevalue: How do you do Hans How are you And now uncle tell me where we are at the present moment

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: To-morrow, Axel, to-morrow. Now you are too faint and weak. I have bandaged your head with compresses which must not be disturbed. Sleep now, and to-morrow I will tell you all.
children.prevalue: To morrow Axel to morrow Now you are too faint and weak I have bandaged your head with compresses which must not be disturbed Sleep now and to morrow I will tell you all

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: But do tell me what time it is, and what day.
children.prevalue: But do tell me what time it is and what day

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: It is Sunday, the 8th of August, and it is ten at night. You must ask me no more questions until the 10th.
children.prevalue: It is Sunday the 8th of August and it is ten at night You must ask me no more questions until the 10th

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: In truth I was very weak, and my eyes involuntarily closed. I wanted a good night's rest; and I therefore went off to sleep, with the knowledge that I had been four long days alone in the heart of the earth.
children.prevalue: In truth I was very weak and my eyes involuntarily closed I wanted a good night s rest and I therefore went off to sleep with the knowledge that I had been four long days alone in the heart of the earth

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Next morning, on awakening, I looked round me. My couch, made up of all our travelling gear, was in a charming grotto, adorned with splendid stalactites, and the soil of which was a fine sand. It was half light. There was no torch, no lamp, yet certain mysterious glimpses of light came from without through a narrow opening in the grotto. I heard too a vague and indistinct noise, something like the murmuring of waves breaking upon a shingly shore, and at times I seemed to hear the whistling of wind.

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I wondered whether I was awake, whether I was dreaming, whether my brain, crazed by my fall, was not affected by imaginary noises. Yet neither eyes, nor ears could be so utterly deceived.
children.prevalue: I wondered whether I was awake whether I was dreaming whether my brain crazed by my fall was not affected by imaginary noises Yet neither eyes nor ears could be so utterly deceived

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It is a ray of daylight, I thought, sliding in through this cleft in the rock! That is indeed the murmuring of waves! That is the rustling noise of wind. Am I quite mistaken, or have we returned to the surface of the earth? Has my uncle given up the expedition, or is it happily terminated?
children.prevalue: It is a ray of daylight I thought sliding in through this cleft in the rock That is indeed the murmuring of waves That is the rustling noise of wind Am I quite mistaken or have we returned to the surface of the earth Has my uncle given up the expedition or is it happily terminated

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: I was asking myself these unanswerable questions when the Professor entered.
children.prevalue: I was asking myself these unanswerable questions when the Professor entered

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Good morning, Axel, he cried cheerily. I feel sure you are better.
children.prevalue: Good morning Axel he cried cheerily I feel sure you are better

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Yes, I am indeed, said I, sitting up on my couch.
children.prevalue: Yes I am indeed said I sitting up on my couch

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: You can hardly fail to be better, for you have slept quietly. Hans and I watched you by turns, and we have noticed you were evidently recovering.
children.prevalue: You can hardly fail to be better for you have slept quietly Hans and I watched you by turns and we have noticed you were evidently recovering

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Indeed, I do feel a great deal better, and I will give you a proof of that presently if you will let me have my breakfast.
children.prevalue: Indeed I do feel a great deal better and I will give you a proof of that presently if you will let me have my breakfast

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: You shall eat, lad. The fever has left you. Hans rubbed your wounds with some ointment or other of which the Icelanders keep the secret, and they have healed marvellously. Our hunter is a splendid fellow!
children.prevalue: You shall eat lad The fever has left you Hans rubbed your wounds with some ointment or other of which the Icelanders keep the secret and they have healed marvellously Our hunter is a splendid fellow

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Whilst he went on talking, my uncle prepared a few provisions, which I devoured eagerly, notwithstanding his advice to the contrary. All the while I was overwhelming him with questions which he answered readily.
children.prevalue: Whilst he went on talking my uncle prepared a few provisions which I devoured eagerly notwithstanding his advice to the contrary All the while I was overwhelming him with questions which he answered readily

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I then learnt that my providential fall had brought me exactly to the extremity of an almost perpendicular shaft; and as I had landed in the midst of an accompanying torrent of stones, the least of which would have been enough to crush me, the conclusion was that a loose portion of the rock had come down with me. This frightful conveyance had thus carried me into the arms of my uncle, where I fell bruised, bleeding, and insensible.

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Truly it is wonderful that you have not been killed a hundred times over. But, for the love of God, don't let us ever separate again, or we many never see each other more.
children.prevalue: Truly it is wonderful that you have not been killed a hundred times over But for the love of God don t let us ever separate again or we many never see each other more

children.value: Not separate! Is the journey not over, then? I opened a pair of astonished eyes, which immediately called for the question:
children.prevalue: Not separate Is the journey not over then I opened a pair of astonished eyes which immediately called for the question

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: What is the matter, Axel?
children.prevalue: What is the matter Axel

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I have a question to ask you. You say that I am safe and sound?
children.prevalue: I have a question to ask you You say that I am safe and sound

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: No doubt you are.
children.prevalue: No doubt you are

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: And all my limbs unbroken?
children.prevalue: And all my limbs unbroken

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: And my head?
children.prevalue: And my head

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Your head, except for a few bruises, is all right; and it is on your shoulders, where it ought to be.
children.prevalue: Your head except for a few bruises is all right and it is on your shoulders where it ought to be

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Well, I am afraid my brain is affected.
children.prevalue: Well I am afraid my brain is affected

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Your mind affected!
children.prevalue: Your mind affected

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Yes, I fear so. Are we again on the surface of the globe?
children.prevalue: Yes I fear so Are we again on the surface of the globe

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: No, certainly not.
children.prevalue: No certainly not

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Then I must be mad; for don't I see the light of day, and don't I hear the wind blowing, and the sea breaking on the shore?
children.prevalue: Then I must be mad for don t I see the light of day and don t I hear the wind blowing and the sea breaking on the shore

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Ah! is that all?
children.prevalue: Ah is that all

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Do tell me all about it.
children.prevalue: Do tell me all about it

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I can't explain the inexplicable, but you will soon see and understand that geology has not yet learnt all it has to learn.
children.prevalue: I can t explain the inexplicable but you will soon see and understand that geology has not yet learnt all it has to learn

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Then let us go, I answered quickly.
children.prevalue: Then let us go I answered quickly

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: No, Axel; the open air might be bad for you.
children.prevalue: No Axel the open air might be bad for you

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Open air?
children.prevalue: Open air

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Yes; the wind is rather strong. You must not expose yourself.
children.prevalue: Yes the wind is rather strong You must not expose yourself

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: But I assure you I am perfectly well.
children.prevalue: But I assure you I am perfectly well

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: A little patience, my nephew. A relapse might get us into trouble, and we have no time to lose, for the voyage may be a long one.
children.prevalue: A little patience my nephew A relapse might get us into trouble and we have no time to lose for the voyage may be a long one

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The voyage!
children.prevalue: The voyage

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Yes, rest to-day, and to-morrow we will set sail.
children.prevalue: Yes rest to day and to morrow we will set sail

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Set sail!--and I almost leaped up.
children.prevalue: Set sail and I almost leaped up

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: What did it all mean? Had we a river, a lake, a sea to depend upon? Was there a ship at our disposal in some underground harbour?
children.prevalue: What did it all mean Had we a river a lake a sea to depend upon Was there a ship at our disposal in some underground harbour

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: My curiosity was highly excited, my uncle vainly tried to restrain me. When he saw that my impatience was doing me harm, he yielded.
children.prevalue: My curiosity was highly excited my uncle vainly tried to restrain me When he saw that my impatience was doing me harm he yielded

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I dressed in haste. For greater safety I wrapped myself in a blanket, and came out of the grotto.
children.prevalue: I dressed in haste For greater safety I wrapped myself in a blanket and came out of the grotto

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: A NEW MARE INTERNUM
children.prevalue: A NEW MARE INTERNUM

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: At first I could hardly see anything. My eyes, unaccustomed to the light, quickly closed. When I was able to reopen them, I stood more stupefied even than surprised.
children.prevalue: At first I could hardly see anything My eyes unaccustomed to the light quickly closed When I was able to reopen them I stood more stupefied even than surprised

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The sea! I cried.
children.prevalue: The sea I cried

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Yes, my uncle replied, the Liedenbrock Sea; and I don't suppose any other discoverer will ever dispute my claim to name it after myself as its first discoverer.
children.prevalue: Yes my uncle replied the Liedenbrock Sea and I don t suppose any other discoverer will ever dispute my claim to name it after myself as its first discoverer

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: A vast sheet of water, the commencement of a lake or an ocean, spread far away beyond the range of the eye, reminding me forcibly of that open sea which drew from Xenophon's ten thousand Greeks, after their long retreat, the simultaneous cry, Thalatta! thalatta! the sea! the sea! The deeply indented shore was lined with a breadth of fine shining sand, softly lapped by the waves, and strewn with the small shells which had been inhabited by the first of created beings. The waves broke on this shore with the hollow echoing murmur peculiar to vast inclosed spaces. A light foam flew over the waves before the breath of a moderate breeze, and some of the spray fell upon my face. On this slightly inclining shore, about a hundred fathoms from the limit of the waves, came down the foot of a huge wall of vast cliffs, which rose majestically to an enormous height. Some of these, dividing the beach with their sharp spurs, formed capes and promontories, worn away by the ceaseless action of the surf. Farther on the eye discerned their massive outline sharply defined against the hazy distant horizon.

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: It was quite an ocean, with the irregular shores of earth, but desert and frightfully wild in appearance.
children.prevalue: It was quite an ocean with the irregular shores of earth but desert and frightfully wild in appearance

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: If my eyes were able to range afar over this great sea, it was because a peculiar light brought to view every detail of it. It was not the light of the sun, with his dazzling shafts of brightness and the splendour of his rays; nor was it the pale and uncertain shimmer of the moonbeams, the dim reflection of a nobler body of light. No; the illuminating power of this light, its trembling diffusiveness, its bright, clear whiteness, and its low temperature, showed that it must be of electric origin. It was like an aurora borealis, a continuous cosmical phenomenon, filling a cavern of sufficient extent to contain an ocean.
children.prevalue: If my eyes were able to range afar over this great sea it was because a peculiar light brought to view every detail of it It was not the light of the sun with his dazzling shafts of brightness and the splendour of his rays nor was it the pale and uncertain shimmer of the moonbeams the dim reflection of a nobler body of light No the illuminating power of this light its trembling diffusiveness its bright clear whiteness and its low temperature showed that it must be of electric origin It was like an aurora borealis a continuous cosmical phenomenon filling a cavern of sufficient extent to contain an ocean

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The vault that spanned the space above, the sky, if it could be called so, seemed composed of vast plains of cloud, shifting and variable vapours, which by their condensation must at certain times fall in torrents of rain. I should have thought that under so powerful a pressure of the atmosphere there could be no evaporation; and yet, under a law unknown to me, there were broad tracts of vapour suspended in the air. But then 'the weather was fine.' The play of the electric light produced singular effects upon the upper strata of cloud. Deep shadows reposed upon their lower wreaths; and often, between two separated fields of cloud, there glided down a ray of unspeakable lustre. But it was not solar light, and there was no heat. The general effect was sad, supremely melancholy. Instead of the shining firmament, spangled with its innumerable stars, shining singly or in clusters, I felt that all these subdued and shaded lights were ribbed in by vast walls of granite, which seemed to overpower me with their weight, and that all this space, great as it was, would not be enough for the march of the humblest of satellites.

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Then I remembered the theory of an English captain, who likened the earth to a vast hollow sphere, in the interior of which the air became luminous because of the vast pressure that weighed upon it; while two stars, Pluto and Proserpine, rolled within upon the circuit of their mysterious orbits.
children.prevalue: Then I remembered the theory of an English captain who likened the earth to a vast hollow sphere in the interior of which the air became luminous because of the vast pressure that weighed upon it while two stars Pluto and Proserpine rolled within upon the circuit of their mysterious orbits

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: We were in reality shut up inside an immeasurable excavation. Its width could not be estimated, since the shore ran widening as far as eye could reach, nor could its length, for the dim horizon bounded the new. As for its height, it must have been several leagues. Where this vault rested upon its granite base no eye could tell; but there was a cloud hanging far above, the height of which we estimated at 12,000 feet, a greater height than that of any terrestrial vapour, and no doubt due to the great density of the air.

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The word cavern does not convey any idea of this immense space; words of human tongue are inadequate to describe the discoveries of him who ventures into the deep abysses of earth.
children.prevalue: The word cavern does not convey any idea of this immense space words of human tongue are inadequate to describe the discoveries of him who ventures into the deep abysses of earth

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Besides I could not tell upon what geological theory to account for the existence of such an excavation. Had the cooling of the globe produced it? I knew of celebrated caverns from the descriptions of travellers, but had never heard of any of such dimensions as this.
children.prevalue: Besides I could not tell upon what geological theory to account for the existence of such an excavation Had the cooling of the globe produced it I knew of celebrated caverns from the descriptions of travellers but had never heard of any of such dimensions as this

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: If the grotto of Guachara, in Colombia, visited by Humboldt, had not given up the whole of the secret of its depth to the philosopher, who investigated it to the depth of 2,500 feet, it probably did not extend much farther. The immense mammoth cave in Kentucky is of gigantic proportions, since its vaulted roof rises five hundred feet [1] above the level of an unfathomable lake and travellers have explored its ramifications to the extent of forty miles. But what were these cavities compared to that in which I stood with wonder and admiration, with its sky of luminous vapours, its bursts of electric light, and a vast sea filling its bed? My imagination fell powerless before such immensity.

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I gazed upon these wonders in silence. Words failed me to express my feelings. I felt as if I was in some distant planet Uranus or Neptune--and in the presence of phenomena of which my terrestrial experience gave me no cognisance. For such novel sensations, new words were wanted; and my imagination failed to supply them. I gazed, I thought, I admired, with a stupefaction mingled with a certain amount of fear.

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The unforeseen nature of this spectacle brought back the colour to my cheeks. I was under a new course of treatment with the aid of astonishment, and my convalescence was promoted by this novel system of therapeutics; besides, the dense and breezy air invigorated me, supplying more oxygen to my lungs.

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It will be easily conceived that after an imprisonment of forty seven days in a narrow gallery it was the height of physical enjoyment to breathe a moist air impregnated with saline particles.
children.prevalue: It will be easily conceived that after an imprisonment of forty seven days in a narrow gallery it was the height of physical enjoyment to breathe a moist air impregnated with saline particles

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: [1] One hundred and twenty. (Trans.)
children.prevalue: 1 One hundred and twenty Trans

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I was delighted to leave my dark grotto. My uncle, already familiar with these wonders, had ceased to feel surprise.
children.prevalue: I was delighted to leave my dark grotto My uncle already familiar with these wonders had ceased to feel surprise

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: You feel strong enough to walk a little way now? he asked.
children.prevalue: You feel strong enough to walk a little way now he asked

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Yes, certainly; and nothing could be more delightful.
children.prevalue: Yes certainly and nothing could be more delightful

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Well, take my arm, Axel, and let us follow the windings of the shore.
children.prevalue: Well take my arm Axel and let us follow the windings of the shore

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I eagerly accepted, and we began to coast along this new sea. On the left huge pyramids of rock, piled one upon another, produced a prodigious titanic effect. Down their sides flowed numberless waterfalls, which went on their way in brawling but pellucid streams. A few light vapours, leaping from rock to rock, denoted the place of hot springs; and streams flowed softly down to the common basin, gliding down the gentle slopes with a softer murmur.

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Amongst these streams I recognised our faithful travelling companion, the Hansbach, coming to lose its little volume quietly in the mighty sea, just as if it had done nothing else since the beginning of the world.
children.prevalue: Amongst these streams I recognised our faithful travelling companion the Hansbach coming to lose its little volume quietly in the mighty sea just as if it had done nothing else since the beginning of the world

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: We shall see it no more, I said, with a sigh.
children.prevalue: We shall see it no more I said with a sigh

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: What matters, replied the philosopher, whether this or another serves to guide us?
children.prevalue: What matters replied the philosopher whether this or another serves to guide us

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I thought him rather ungrateful.
children.prevalue: I thought him rather ungrateful

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: But at that moment my attention was drawn to an unexpected sight. At a distance of five hundred paces, at the turn of a high promontory, appeared a high, tufted, dense forest. It was composed of trees of moderate height, formed like umbrellas, with exact geometrical outlines. The currents of wind seemed to have had no effect upon their shape, and in the midst of the windy blasts they stood unmoved and firm, just like a clump of petrified cedars.

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I hastened forward. I could not give any name to these singular creations. Were they some of the two hundred thousand species of vegetables known hitherto, and did they claim a place of their own in the lacustrine flora? No; when we arrived under their shade my surprise turned into admiration. There stood before me productions of earth, but of gigantic stature, which my uncle immediately named.

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: It is only a forest of mushrooms, said he.
children.prevalue: It is only a forest of mushrooms said he

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: And he was right. Imagine the large development attained by these plants, which prefer a warm, moist climate. I knew that the _Lycopodon giganteum_ attains, according to Bulliard, a circumference of eight or nine feet; but here were pale mushrooms, thirty to forty feet high, and crowned with a cap of equal diameter. There they stood in thousands. No light could penetrate between their huge cones, and complete darkness reigned beneath those giants; they formed settlements of domes placed in close array like the round, thatched roofs of a central African city.

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Yet I wanted to penetrate farther underneath, though a chill fell upon me as soon as I came under those cellular vaults. For half an hour we wandered from side to side in the damp shades, and it was a comfortable and pleasant change to arrive once more upon the sea shore.

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: But the subterranean vegetation was not confined to these fungi. Farther on rose groups of tall trees of colourless foliage and easy to recognise. They were lowly shrubs of earth, here attaining gigantic size; lycopodiums, a hundred feet high; the huge sigillaria, found in our coal mines; tree ferns, as tall as our fir-trees in northern latitudes; lepidodendra, with cylindrical forked stems, terminated by long leaves, and bristling with rough hairs like those of the cactus.

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Wonderful, magnificent, splendid! cried my uncle. Here is the entire flora of the second period of the world--the transition period. These, humble garden plants with us, were tall trees in the early ages. Look, Axel, and admire it all. Never had botanist such a feast as this!

children.prevalue: It is a conservatory Axel but is it not also a menagerie

children.name: Paragraph_36

children.prevalue: Surely not a menagerie

children.value: Yes; no doubt of it. Look at that dust under your feet; see the bones scattered on the ground.

children.prevalue: So there are I cried bones of extinct animals

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I had rushed upon these remains, formed of indestructible phosphates of lime, and without hesitation I named these monstrous bones, which lay scattered about like decayed trunks of trees.

children.value: Here is the lower jaw of a mastodon, [1] I said. These are the molar teeth of the deinotherium; this femur must have belonged to the greatest of those beasts, the megatherium. It certainly is a menagerie, for these remains were not brought here by a deluge. The animals to which they belonged roamed on the shores of this subterranean sea, under the shade of those arborescent trees. Here are entire skeletons. And yet I cannot understand the appearance of these quadrupeds in a granite cavern.

children.prevalue: Why

children.value: Because animal life existed upon the earth only in the secondary period, when a sediment of soil had been deposited by the rivers, and taken the place of the incandescent rocks of the primitive period.
children.prevalue: Because animal life existed upon the earth only in the secondary period when a sediment of soil had been deposited by the rivers and taken the place of the incandescent rocks of the primitive period

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Well, Axel, there is a very simple answer to your objection that this soil is alluvial.
children.prevalue: Well Axel there is a very simple answer to your objection that this soil is alluvial

children.prevalue: What at such a depth below the surface of the earth

children.value: No doubt; and there is a geological explanation of the fact. children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: That may be, I replied; but if there have been creatures now extinct in these underground regions, why may not some of those monsters be now roaming through these gloomy forests, or hidden behind the steep crags?
children.prevalue: That may be I replied but if there have been creatures now extinct in these underground regions why may not some of those monsters be now roaming through these gloomy forests or hidden behind the steep crags

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And as this unpleasant notion got hold of me, I surveyed with anxious scrutiny the open spaces before me; but no living creature appeared upon the barren strand.

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: I felt rather tired, and went to sit down at the end of a promontory, at the foot of which the waves came and beat themselves into spray. Thence my eye could sweep every part of the bay; within its extremity a little harbour was formed between the pyramidal cliffs, where the still waters slept untouched by the boisterous winds. A brig and two or three schooners might have moored within it in safety. I almost fancied I should presently see some ship issue from it, full sail, and take to the open sea under the southern breeze.

children.value: But this illusion lasted a very short time. We were the only living creatures in this subterranean world. When the wind lulled, a deeper silence than that of the deserts fell upon the arid, naked rocks, and weighed upon the surface of the ocean. I then desired to pierce the distant haze, and to rend asunder the mysterious curtain that hung across the horizon. Anxious queries arose to my lips. Where did that sea terminate? Where did it lead to? Should we ever know anything about its opposite shores?

children.value: My uncle made no doubt about it at all; I both desired and feared.
children.prevalue: My uncle made no doubt about it at all I both desired and feared

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: After spending an hour in the contemplation of this marvellous spectacle, we returned to the shore to regain the grotto, and I fell asleep in the midst of the strangest thoughts.

children.prevalue: PREPARATIONS FOR A VOYAGE OF DISCOVERY

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The next morning I awoke feeling perfectly well. I thought a bathe would do me good, and I went to plunge for a few minutes into the waters of this mediterranean sea, for assuredly it better deserved this name than any other sea.

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: I came back to breakfast with a good appetite. Hans was a good caterer for our little household; he had water and fire at his disposal, so that he was able to vary our bill of fare now and then. For dessert he gave us a few cups of coffee, and never was coffee so delicious.

children.prevalue: What the tide I cried Can the influence of the sun and moon be felt down here

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Why not? Are not all bodies subject throughout their mass to the power of universal attraction? This mass of water cannot escape the general law. And in spite of the heavy atmospheric pressure on the surface, you will see it rise like the Atlantic itself.

children.name: Paragraph_7

children.prevalue: At the same moment we reached the sand on the shore and the waves were by slow degrees encroaching on the shore

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Here is the tide rising, I cried.
children.prevalue: Here is the tide rising I cried

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Yes, Axel; and judging by these ridges of foam, you may observe that the sea will rise about twelve feet.
children.prevalue: Yes Axel and judging by these ridges of foam you may observe that the sea will rise about twelve feet

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: This is wonderful, I said.
children.prevalue: This is wonderful I said

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: No; it is quite natural.
children.prevalue: No it is quite natural

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: You may say so, uncle; but to me it is most extraordinary, and I can hardly believe my eyes. Who would ever have imagined, under this terrestrial crust, an ocean with ebbing and flowing tides, with winds and storms?
children.prevalue: You may say so uncle but to me it is most extraordinary and I can hardly believe my eyes Who would ever have imagined under this terrestrial crust an ocean with ebbing and flowing tides with winds and storms

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Well, replied my uncle, is there any scientific reason against it?
children.prevalue: Well replied my uncle is there any scientific reason against it

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: No; I see none, as soon as the theory of central heat is given up. So then, thus far, he answered, the theory of Sir Humphry Davy is confirmed.
children.prevalue: No I see none as soon as the theory of central heat is given up So then thus far he answered the theory of Sir Humphry Davy is confirmed

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Evidently it is; and now there is no reason why there should not be seas and continents in the interior of the earth.
children.prevalue: Evidently it is and now there is no reason why there should not be seas and continents in the interior of the earth

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: No doubt, said my uncle; and inhabited too.
children.prevalue: No doubt said my uncle and inhabited too

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: To be sure, said I; and why should not these waters yield to us fishes of unknown species?
children.prevalue: To be sure said I and why should not these waters yield to us fishes of unknown species

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: At any rate, he replied, we have not seen any yet.
children.prevalue: At any rate he replied we have not seen any yet

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Well, let us make some lines, and see if the bait will draw here as it does in sublunary regions.
children.prevalue: Well let us make some lines and see if the bait will draw here as it does in sublunary regions

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: We will try, Axel, for we must penetrate all secrets of these newly discovered regions.
children.prevalue: We will try Axel for we must penetrate all secrets of these newly discovered regions

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: But where are we, uncle? for I have not yet asked you that question, and your instruments must be able to furnish the answer.
children.prevalue: But where are we uncle for I have not yet asked you that question and your instruments must be able to furnish the answer

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Horizontally, three hundred and fifty leagues from Iceland.
children.prevalue: Horizontally three hundred and fifty leagues from Iceland

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: So much as that?
children.prevalue: So much as that

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I am sure of not being a mile out of my reckoning.
children.prevalue: I am sure of not being a mile out of my reckoning

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: And does the compass still show south-east?
children.prevalue: And does the compass still show south east

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Yes; with a westerly deviation of nineteen degrees forty-five minutes, just as above ground. As for its dip, a curious fact is coming to light, which I have observed carefully: that the needle, instead of dipping towards the pole as in the northern hemisphere, on the contrary, rises from it.

children.value: Exactly so; and it is likely enough that if we were to reach the spot beneath the polar regions, about that seventy-first degree where Sir James Ross has discovered the magnetic pole to be situated, we should see the needle point straight up. Therefore that mysterious centre of attraction is at no great depth.

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I remarked: It is so; and here is a fact which science has scarcely suspected.
children.prevalue: I remarked It is so and here is a fact which science has scarcely suspected

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Science, my lad, has been built upon many errors; but they are errors which it was good to fall into, for they led to the truth.

children.value: What depth have we now reached?
children.prevalue: What depth have we now reached

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: We are thirty-five leagues below the surface.
children.prevalue: We are thirty five leagues below the surface

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: So, I said, examining the map, the Highlands of Scotland are over our heads, and the Grampians are raising their rugged summits above us.
children.prevalue: So I said examining the map the Highlands of Scotland are over our heads and the Grampians are raising their rugged summits above us

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Yes, answered the Professor laughing. It is rather a heavy weight to bear, but a solid arch spans over our heads. The great Architect has built it of the best materials; and never could man have given it so wide a stretch. What are the finest arches of bridges and the arcades of cathedrals, compared with this far reaching vault, with a radius of three leagues, beneath which a wide and tempest-tossed ocean may flow at its ease?

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Oh, I am not afraid that it will fall down upon my head. But now what are your plans? Are you not thinking of returning to the surface now?
children.prevalue: Oh I am not afraid that it will fall down upon my head But now what are your plans Are you not thinking of returning to the surface now

children.prevalue: Return no indeed We will continue our journey everything having gone on well so far

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: But how are we to get down below this liquid surface?
children.prevalue: But how are we to get down below this liquid surface

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Oh, I am not going to dive head foremost. But if all oceans are properly speaking but lakes, since they are encompassed by land, of course this internal sea will be surrounded by a coast of granite, and on the opposite shores we shall find fresh passages opening.

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: How long do you suppose this sea to be?
children.prevalue: How long do you suppose this sea to be

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Thirty or forty leagues; so that we have no time to lose, and we shall set sail to-morrow.
children.prevalue: Thirty or forty leagues so that we have no time to lose and we shall set sail to morrow

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I looked about for a ship.
children.prevalue: I looked about for a ship

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Set sail, shall we? But I should like to see my boat first.
children.prevalue: Set sail shall we But I should like to see my boat first

children.prevalue: It will not be a boat at all but a good well made raft

children.name: Paragraph_44

children.prevalue: Why I said a raft would be just as hard to make as a boat and I don t see

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: I know you don't see; but you might hear if you would listen. Don't you hear the hammer at work? Hans is already busy at it.
children.prevalue: I know you don t see but you might hear if you would listen Don t you hear the hammer at work Hans is already busy at it

children.value: What, has he already felled the trees?
children.prevalue: What has he already felled the trees

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Oh, the trees were already down. Come, and you will see for yourself.
children.prevalue: Oh the trees were already down Come and you will see for yourself

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: After half an hour's walking, on the other side of the promontory which formed the little natural harbour, I perceived Hans at work. In a few more steps I was at his side. To my great surprise a half-finished raft was already lying on the sand, made of a peculiar kind of wood, and a great number of planks, straight and bent, and of frames, were covering the ground, enough almost for a little fleet.

children.prevalue: Uncle what wood is this I cried

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: It is fir, pine, or birch, and other northern coniferae, mineralised by the action of the sea. It is called surturbrand, a variety of brown coal or lignite, found chiefly in Iceland.

children.name: Paragraph_51

children.prevalue: But surely then like other fossil wood it must be as hard as stone and cannot float

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Sometimes that may happen; some of these woods become true anthracites; but others, such as this, have only gone through the first stage of fossil transformation. Just look, added my uncle, throwing into the sea one of those precious waifs.

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Are you convinced? said my uncle.
children.prevalue: Are you convinced said my uncle

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I am quite convinced, although it is incredible!
children.prevalue: I am quite convinced although it is incredible

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: On the 13th of August we awoke early. We were now to begin to adopt a mode of travelling both more expeditious and less fatiguing than hitherto.

children.prevalue: And so the cherished remembrance of my Virlandaise became associated with our adventurous expedition

children.name: Paragraph_8

children.prevalue: The wind was from the north west We went with it at a high rate of speed The dense atmosphere acted with great force and impelled us swiftly on

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: In an hour my uncle had been able to estimate our progress. At this rate, he said, we shall make thirty leagues in twenty-four hours, and we shall soon come in sight of the opposite shore.

children.value: I made no answer, but went and sat forward. The northern shore was already beginning to dip under the horizon. The eastern and western strands spread wide as if to bid us farewell. Soon we entirely lost sight of land; no object was left for the eye to judge by, and but for the frothy track of the raft, I might have thought we were standing still.

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: About twelve, immense shoals of seaweeds came in sight. I was aware of the great powers of vegetation that characterise these plants, which grow at a depth of twelve thousand feet, reproduce themselves under a pressure of four hundred atmospheres, and sometimes form barriers strong enough to impede the course of a ship. But never, I think, were such seaweeds as those which we saw floating in immense waving lines upon the sea of Liedenbrock.

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Still my imagination carried me away amongst the wonderful speculations of palæontology. Though awake I fell into a dream. I thought I could see floating on the surface of the waters enormous chelonia, pre-adamite tortoises, resembling floating islands. Over the dimly lighted strand there trod the huge mammals of the first ages of the world, the leptotherium (slender beast), found in the caverns of Brazil; the merycotherium (ruminating beast), found in the 'drift' of iceclad Siberia. Farther on, the pachydermatous lophiodon (crested toothed), a gigantic tapir, hides behind the rocks to dispute its prey with the anoplotherium (unarmed beast), a strange creature, which seemed a compound of horse, rhinoceros, camel, and hippopotamus. The colossal mastodon (nipple-toothed) twists and untwists his trunk, and brays and pounds with his huge tusks the fragments of rock that cover the shore; whilst the megatherium (huge beast), buttressed upon his enormous hinder paws, grubs in the soil, awaking the sonorous echoes of the granite rocks with his tremendous roarings. Higher up, the protopitheca--the first monkey that appeared on the globe--is climbing up the steep ascents. Higher yet, the pterodactyle (wing-fingered) darts in irregular zigzags to and fro in the heavy air. In the uppermost regions of the air immense birds, more powerful than the cassowary, and larger than the ostrich, spread their vast breadth of wings and strike with their heads the granite vault that bounds the sky.

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: All this fossil world rises to life again in my vivid imagination. I return to the scriptural periods or ages of the world, conventionally called 'days,' long before the appearance of man, when the unfinished world was as yet unfitted for his support. Then my dream backed even farther still into the ages before the creation of living beings. The mammals disappear, then the birds vanish, then the reptiles of the secondary period, and finally the fish, the crustaceans, molluscs, and articulated beings. Then the zoophytes of the transition period also return to nothing. I am the only living thing in the world: all life is concentrated in my beating heart alone. There are no more seasons; climates are no more; the heat of the globe continually increases and neutralises that of the sun. Vegetation becomes accelerated. I glide like a shade amongst arborescent ferns, treading with unsteady feet the coloured marls and the particoloured clays; I lean for support against the trunks of immense conifers; I lie in the shade of sphenophylla (wedge-leaved), asterophylla (star-leaved), and lycopods, a hundred feet high.

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Ages seem no more than days! I am passed, against my will, in retrograde order, through the long series of terrestrial changes. Plants disappear; granite rocks soften; intense heat converts solid bodies into thick fluids; the waters again cover the face of the earth; they boil, they rise in whirling eddies of steam; white and ghastly mists wrap round the shifting forms of the earth, which by imperceptible degrees dissolves into a gaseous mass, glowing fiery red and white, as large and as shining as the sun.

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: And I myself am floating with wild caprice in the midst of this nebulous mass of fourteen hundred thousand times the volume of the earth into which it will one day be condensed, and carried forward amongst the planetary bodies. My body is no longer firm and terrestrial; it is resolved into its constituent atoms, subtilised, volatilised. Sublimed into imponderable vapour, I mingle and am lost in the endless foods of those vast globular volumes of vaporous mists, which roll upon their flaming orbits through infinite space.
