children.value: Yes, said my uncle, was he stopped by this stone barrier?
children.prevalue: Yes said my uncle was he stopped by this stone barrier

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: No, no, I replied with animation. This fragment of rock has been shaken down by some shock or convulsion, or by one of those magnetic storms which agitate these regions, and has blocked up the passage which lay open to him. Many years have elapsed since the return of Saknussemm to the surface and the fall of this huge fragment. Is it not evident that this gallery was once the way open to the course of the lava, and that at that time there must have been a free passage? See here are recent fissures grooving and channelling the granite roof. This roof itself is formed of fragments of rock carried down, of enormous stones, as if by some giant's hand; but at one time the expulsive force was greater than usual, and this block, like the falling keystone of a ruined arch, has slipped down to the ground and blocked up the way. It is only an accidental obstruction, not met by Saknussemm, and if we don't destroy it we shall be unworthy to reach the centre of the earth.

children.value: Such was my sentence! The soul of the Professor had passed into me. The genius of discovery possessed me wholly. I forgot the past, I scorned the future. children.prevalue: Too hard for the pickaxe

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The next day, Thursday, August 27, is a well-remembered date in our subterranean journey. It never returns to my memory without sending through me a shudder of horror and a palpitation of the heart. From that hour we had no further occasion for the exercise of reason, or judgment, or skill, or contrivance. We were henceforth to be hurled along, the playthings of the fierce elements of the deep.

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: An hour passed away--two hours, perhaps--I cannot tell. We clutched each other fast, to save ourselves from being thrown off the raft. We felt violent shocks whenever we were borne heavily against the craggy projections. Yet these shocks were not very frequent, from which I concluded that the gully was widening. It was no doubt the same road that Saknussemm had taken; but instead of walking peaceably down it, as he had done, we were carrying a whole sea along with us.
children.prevalue: An hour passed away two hours perhaps I cannot tell We clutched each other fast to save ourselves from being thrown off the raft We felt violent shocks whenever we were borne heavily against the craggy projections Yet these shocks were not very frequent from which I concluded that the gully was widening It was no doubt the same road that Saknussemm had taken but instead of walking peaceably down it as he had done we were carrying a whole sea along with us

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: These ideas, it will be understood, presented themselves to my mind in a vague and undetermined form. I had difficulty in associating any ideas together during this headlong race, which seemed like a vertical descent. To judge by the air which was whistling past me and made a whizzing in my ears, we were moving faster than the fastest express trains. To light a torch under these' conditions would have been impossible; and our last electric apparatus had been shattered by the force of the explosion.
children.prevalue: These ideas it will be understood presented themselves to my mind in a vague and undetermined form I had difficulty in associating any ideas together during this headlong race which seemed like a vertical descent To judge by the air which was whistling past me and made a whizzing in my ears we were moving faster than the fastest express trains To light a torch under these conditions would have been impossible and our last electric apparatus had been shattered by the force of the explosion

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I was therefore much surprised to see a clear light shining near me. It lighted up the calm and unmoved countenance of Hans. The skilful huntsman had succeeded in lighting the lantern; and although it flickered so much as to threaten to go out, it threw a fitful light across the awful darkness.
children.prevalue: I was therefore much surprised to see a clear light shining near me It lighted up the calm and unmoved countenance of Hans The skilful huntsman had succeeded in lighting the lantern and although it flickered so much as to threaten to go out it threw a fitful light across the awful darkness

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I was right in my supposition. It was a wide gallery. The dim light could not show us both its walls at once. The fall of the waters which were carrying us away exceeded that of the swiftest rapids in American rivers. Its surface seemed composed of a sheaf of arrows hurled with inconceivable force; I cannot convey my impressions by a better comparison. The raft, occasionally seized by an eddy, spun round as it still flew along. When it approached the walls of the gallery I threw on them the light of the lantern, and I could judge somewhat of the velocity of our speed by noticing how the jagged projections of the rocks spun into endless ribbons and bands, so that we seemed confined within a network of shifting lines. I supposed we were running at the rate of thirty leagues an hour.
children.prevalue: I was right in my supposition It was a wide gallery The dim light could not show us both its walls at once The fall of the waters which were carrying us away exceeded that of the swiftest rapids in American rivers Its surface seemed composed of a sheaf of arrows hurled with inconceivable force I cannot convey my impressions by a better comparison The raft occasionally seized by an eddy spun round as it still flew along When it approached the walls of the gallery I threw on them the light of the lantern and I could judge somewhat of the velocity of our speed by noticing how the jagged projections of the rocks spun into endless ribbons and bands so that we seemed confined within a network of shifting lines I supposed we were running at the rate of thirty leagues an hour

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: My uncle and I gazed on each other with haggard eyes, clinging to the stump of the mast, which had snapped asunder at the first shock of our great catastrophe. We kept our backs to the wind, not to be stifled by the rapidity of a movement which no human power could check.
children.prevalue: My uncle and I gazed on each other with haggard eyes clinging to the stump of the mast which had snapped asunder at the first shock of our great catastrophe We kept our backs to the wind not to be stifled by the rapidity of a movement which no human power could check

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Hours passed away. No change in our situation; but a discovery came to complicate matters and make them worse.
children.prevalue: Hours passed away No change in our situation but a discovery came to complicate matters and make them worse

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: In seeking to put our cargo into somewhat better order, I found that the greater part of the articles embarked had disappeared at the moment of the explosion, when the sea broke in upon us with such violence. I wanted to know exactly what we had saved, and with the lantern in my hand I began my examination. Of our instruments none were saved but the compass and the chronometer; our stock of ropes and ladders was reduced to the bit of cord rolled round the stump of the mast! Not a spade, not a pickaxe, not a hammer was left us; and, irreparable disaster! we had only one day's provisions left.
children.prevalue: In seeking to put our cargo into somewhat better order I found that the greater part of the articles embarked had disappeared at the moment of the explosion when the sea broke in upon us with such violence I wanted to know exactly what we had saved and with the lantern in my hand I began my examination Of our instruments none were saved but the compass and the chronometer our stock of ropes and ladders was reduced to the bit of cord rolled round the stump of the mast Not a spade not a pickaxe not a hammer was left us and irreparable disaster we had only one day s provisions left

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I searched every nook and corner, every crack and cranny in the raft. There was nothing. Our provisions were reduced to one bit of salt meat and a few biscuits.
children.prevalue: I searched every nook and corner every crack and cranny in the raft There was nothing Our provisions were reduced to one bit of salt meat and a few biscuits

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I stared at our failing supplies stupidly. I refused to take in the gravity of our loss. And yet what was the use of troubling myself. If we had had provisions enough for months, how could we get out of the abyss into which we were being hurled by an irresistible torrent? Why should we fear the horrors of famine, when death was swooping down upon us in a multitude of other forms? Would there be time left to die of starvation?
children.prevalue: I stared at our failing supplies stupidly I refused to take in the gravity of our loss And yet what was the use of troubling myself If we had had provisions enough for months how could we get out of the abyss into which we were being hurled by an irresistible torrent Why should we fear the horrors of famine when death was swooping down upon us in a multitude of other forms Would there be time left to die of starvation

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Yet by an inexplicable play of the imagination I forgot my present dangers, to contemplate the threatening future. Was there any chance of escaping from the fury of this impetuous torrent, and of returning to the surface of the globe? I could not form the slightest conjecture how or when. But one chance in a thousand, or ten thousand, is still a chance; whilst death from starvation would leave us not the smallest hope in the world.
children.prevalue: Yet by an inexplicable play of the imagination I forgot my present dangers to contemplate the threatening future Was there any chance of escaping from the fury of this impetuous torrent and of returning to the surface of the globe I could not form the slightest conjecture how or when But one chance in a thousand or ten thousand is still a chance whilst death from starvation would leave us not the smallest hope in the world

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The thought came into my mind to declare the whole truth to my uncle, to show him the dreadful straits to which we were reduced, and to calculate how long we might yet expect to live. But I had the courage to preserve silence. I wished to leave him cool and self-possessed.
children.prevalue: The thought came into my mind to declare the whole truth to my uncle to show him the dreadful straits to which we were reduced and to calculate how long we might yet expect to live But I had the courage to preserve silence I wished to leave him cool and self possessed

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: At that moment the light from our lantern began to sink by little and little, and then went out entirely. The wick had burnt itself out. Black night reigned again; and there was no hope left of being able to dissipate the palpable darkness. We had yet a torch left, but we could not have kept it alight. Then, like a child, I closed my eyes firmly, not to see the darkness.
children.prevalue: At that moment the light from our lantern began to sink by little and little and then went out entirely The wick had burnt itself out Black night reigned again and there was no hope left of being able to dissipate the palpable darkness We had yet a torch left but we could not have kept it alight Then like a child I closed my eyes firmly not to see the darkness

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: After a considerable lapse of time our speed redoubled. I could perceive it by the sharpness of the currents that blew past my face. The descent became steeper. I believe we were no longer sliding, but falling down. I had an impression that we were dropping vertically. My uncle's hand, and the vigorous arm of Hans, held me fast.
children.prevalue: After a considerable lapse of time our speed redoubled I could perceive it by the sharpness of the currents that blew past my face The descent became steeper I believe we were no longer sliding but falling down I had an impression that we were dropping vertically My uncle s hand and the vigorous arm of Hans held me fast

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Suddenly, after a space of time that I could not measure, I felt a shock. The raft had not struck against any hard resistance, but had suddenly been checked in its fall. A waterspout, an immense liquid column, was beating upon the surface of the waters. I was suffocating! I was drowning!
children.prevalue: Suddenly after a space of time that I could not measure I felt a shock The raft had not struck against any hard resistance but had suddenly been checked in its fall A waterspout an immense liquid column was beating upon the surface of the waters I was suffocating I was drowning

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: But this sudden flood was not of long duration. In a few seconds I found myself in the air again, which I inhaled with all the force of my lungs. My uncle and Hans were still holding me fast by the arms; and the raft was still carrying us.
children.prevalue: But this sudden flood was not of long duration In a few seconds I found myself in the air again which I inhaled with all the force of my lungs My uncle and Hans were still holding me fast by the arms and the raft was still carrying us

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: HEADLONG SPEED UPWARD THROUGH THE HORRORS OF DARKNESS
children.prevalue: HEADLONG SPEED UPWARD THROUGH THE HORRORS OF DARKNESS

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It might have been, as I guessed, about ten at night. The first of my senses which came into play after this last bout was that of hearing. All at once I could hear; and it was a real exercise of the sense of hearing. I could hear the silence in the gallery after the din which for hours had stunned me. At last these words of my uncle's came to me like a vague murmuring:
children.prevalue: It might have been as I guessed about ten at night The first of my senses which came into play after this last bout was that of hearing All at once I could hear and it was a real exercise of the sense of hearing I could hear the silence in the gallery after the din which for hours had stunned me At last these words of my uncle s came to me like a vague murmuring

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: We are going up.
children.prevalue: We are going up

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: What do you mean? I cried.
children.prevalue: What do you mean I cried

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Yes, we are going up--up!
children.prevalue: Yes we are going up up

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I stretched out my arm. I touched the wall, and drew back my hand bleeding. We were ascending with extreme rapidity.
children.prevalue: I stretched out my arm I touched the wall and drew back my hand bleeding We were ascending with extreme rapidity

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The torch! The torch! cried the Professor.
children.prevalue: The torch The torch cried the Professor

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Not without difficulty Hans succeeded in lighting the torch; and the flame, preserving its upward tendency, threw enough light to show us what kind of a place we were in.
children.prevalue: Not without difficulty Hans succeeded in lighting the torch and the flame preserving its upward tendency threw enough light to show us what kind of a place we were in

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Just as I thought, said the Professor We are in a tunnel not four-and-twenty feet in diameter. The water had reached the bottom of the gulf. It is now rising to its level, and carrying us with it.
children.prevalue: Just as I thought said the Professor We are in a tunnel not four and twenty feet in diameter The water had reached the bottom of the gulf It is now rising to its level and carrying us with it

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Where to?
children.prevalue: Where to

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I cannot tell; but we must be ready for anything. We are mounting at a speed which seems to me of fourteen feet in a second, or ten miles an hour. At this rate we shall get on.
children.prevalue: I cannot tell but we must be ready for anything We are mounting at a speed which seems to me of fourteen feet in a second or ten miles an hour At this rate we shall get on

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Yes, if nothing stops us; if this well has an aperture. But suppose it to be stopped. If the air is condensed by the pressure of this column of water we shall be crushed.
children.prevalue: Yes if nothing stops us if this well has an aperture But suppose it to be stopped If the air is condensed by the pressure of this column of water we shall be crushed

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Axel, replied the Professor with perfect coolness, our situation is almost desperate; but there are some chances of deliverance, and it is these that I am considering. If at every instant we may perish, so at every instant we may be saved. Let us then be prepared to seize upon the smallest advantage.
children.prevalue: Axel replied the Professor with perfect coolness our situation is almost desperate but there are some chances of deliverance and it is these that I am considering If at every instant we may perish so at every instant we may be saved Let us then be prepared to seize upon the smallest advantage

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: But what shall we do now?
children.prevalue: But what shall we do now

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Recruit our strength by eating.
children.prevalue: Recruit our strength by eating

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: At these words I fixed a haggard eye upon my uncle. That which I had been so unwilling to confess at last had to be told.
children.prevalue: At these words I fixed a haggard eye upon my uncle That which I had been so unwilling to confess at last had to be told

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Eat, did you say?
children.prevalue: Eat did you say

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Yes, at once.
children.prevalue: Yes at once

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The Professor added a few words in Danish, but Hans shook his head mournfully.
children.prevalue: The Professor added a few words in Danish but Hans shook his head mournfully

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What! cried my uncle. Have we lost our provisions?
children.prevalue: What cried my uncle Have we lost our provisions

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Yes; here is all we have left; one bit of salt meat for the three.
children.prevalue: Yes here is all we have left one bit of salt meat for the three

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: My uncle stared at me as if he could not understand.
children.prevalue: My uncle stared at me as if he could not understand

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Well, said I, do you think we have any chance of being saved?
children.prevalue: Well said I do you think we have any chance of being saved

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: My question was unanswered.
children.prevalue: My question was unanswered

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: An hour passed away. I began to feel the pangs of a violent hunger. My companions were suffering too, and not one of us dared touch this wretched remnant of our goodly store.
children.prevalue: An hour passed away I began to feel the pangs of a violent hunger My companions were suffering too and not one of us dared touch this wretched remnant of our goodly store

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: But now we were mounting up with excessive speed. Sometimes the air would cut our breath short, as is experienced by aeronauts ascending too rapidly. But whilst they suffer from cold in proportion to their rise, we were beginning to feel a contrary effect. The heat was increasing in a manner to cause us the most fearful anxiety, and certainly the temperature was at this moment at the height of 100° Fahr.
children.prevalue: But now we were mounting up with excessive speed Sometimes the air would cut our breath short as is experienced by aeronauts ascending too rapidly But whilst they suffer from cold in proportion to their rise we were beginning to feel a contrary effect The heat was increasing in a manner to cause us the most fearful anxiety and certainly the temperature was at this moment at the height of 100° Fahr

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: What could be the meaning of such a change? Up to this time facts had supported the theories of Davy and of Liedenbrock; until now particular conditions of non-conducting rocks, electricity and magnetism, had tempered the laws of nature, giving us only a moderately warm climate, for the theory of a central fire remained in my estimation the only one that was true and explicable. Were we then turning back to where the phenomena of central heat ruled in all their rigour and would reduce the most refractory rocks to the state of a molten liquid? I feared this, and said to the Professor:

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: If we are neither drowned, nor shattered to pieces, nor starved to death, there is still the chance that we may be burned alive and reduced to ashes.
children.prevalue: If we are neither drowned nor shattered to pieces nor starved to death there is still the chance that we may be burned alive and reduced to ashes

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: At this he shrugged his shoulders and returned to his thoughts.
children.prevalue: At this he shrugged his shoulders and returned to his thoughts

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Another hour passed, and, except some slight increase in the temperature, nothing new had happened.
children.prevalue: Another hour passed and except some slight increase in the temperature nothing new had happened

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Come, said he, we must determine upon something.
children.prevalue: Come said he we must determine upon something

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Determine on what? said I.
children.prevalue: Determine on what said I

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Yes, we must recruit our strength by carefully rationing ourselves, and so prolong our existence by a few hours. But we shall be reduced to very great weakness at last.
children.prevalue: Yes we must recruit our strength by carefully rationing ourselves and so prolong our existence by a few hours But we shall be reduced to very great weakness at last

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: And our last hour is not far off.
children.prevalue: And our last hour is not far off

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Well, if there is a chance of safety, if a moment for active exertion presents itself, where should we find the required strength if we allowed ourselves to be enfeebled by hunger?
children.prevalue: Well if there is a chance of safety if a moment for active exertion presents itself where should we find the required strength if we allowed ourselves to be enfeebled by hunger

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Well, uncle, when this bit of meat has been devoured what shall we have left?
children.prevalue: Well uncle when this bit of meat has been devoured what shall we have left

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Nothing, Axel, nothing at all. But will it do you any more good to devour it with your eyes than with your teeth? Your reasoning has in it neither sense nor energy.
children.prevalue: Nothing Axel nothing at all But will it do you any more good to devour it with your eyes than with your teeth Your reasoning has in it neither sense nor energy

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Then don't you despair? I cried irritably.
children.prevalue: Then don t you despair I cried irritably

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: No, certainly not, was the Professor's firm reply.
children.prevalue: No certainly not was the Professor s firm reply

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: What! do you think there is any chance of safety left?
children.prevalue: What do you think there is any chance of safety left

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Yes, I do; as long as the heart beats, as long as body and soul keep together, I cannot admit that any creature endowed with a will has need to despair of life.
children.prevalue: Yes I do as long as the heart beats as long as body and soul keep together I cannot admit that any creature endowed with a will has need to despair of life

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Resolute words these! The man who could speak so, under such circumstances, was of no ordinary type.
children.prevalue: Resolute words these The man who could speak so under such circumstances was of no ordinary type

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Finally, what do you mean to do? I asked.
children.prevalue: Finally what do you mean to do I asked

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Eat what is left to the last crumb, and recruit our fading strength. This meal will be our last, perhaps: so let it be! But at any rate we shall once more be men, and not exhausted, empty bags.
children.prevalue: Eat what is left to the last crumb and recruit our fading strength This meal will be our last perhaps so let it be But at any rate we shall once more be men and not exhausted empty bags

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Well, let us consume it then, I cried.
children.prevalue: Well let us consume it then I cried

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: My uncle took the piece of meat and the few biscuits which had escaped from the general destruction. He divided them into three equal portions and gave one to each. This made about a pound of nourishment for each. The Professor ate his greedily, with a kind of feverish rage. I ate without pleasure, almost with disgust; Hans quietly, moderately, masticating his small mouthfuls without any noise, and relishing them with the calmness of a man above all anxiety about the future. By diligent search he had found a flask of Hollands; he offered it to us each in turn, and this generous beverage cheered us up slightly.

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: _Forträfflig,_ said Hans, drinking in his turn.
children.prevalue: Forträfflig said Hans drinking in his turn

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Excellent, replied my uncle.
children.prevalue: Excellent replied my uncle

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: A glimpse of hope had returned, although without cause. But our last meal was over, and it was now five in the morning.
children.prevalue: A glimpse of hope had returned although without cause But our last meal was over and it was now five in the morning

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Man is so constituted that health is a purely negative state. Hunger once satisfied, it is difficult for a man to imagine the horrors of starvation; they cannot be understood without being felt.
children.prevalue: Man is so constituted that health is a purely negative state Hunger once satisfied it is difficult for a man to imagine the horrors of starvation they cannot be understood without being felt

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Therefore it was that after our long fast these few mouthfuls of meat and biscuit made us triumph over our past agonies.
children.prevalue: Therefore it was that after our long fast these few mouthfuls of meat and biscuit made us triumph over our past agonies

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: But as soon as the meal was done, we each of us fell deep into thought. What was Hans thinking of--that man of the far West, but who seemed ruled by the fatalist doctrines of the East?
children.prevalue: But as soon as the meal was done we each of us fell deep into thought What was Hans thinking of that man of the far West but who seemed ruled by the fatalist doctrines of the East

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: As for me, my thoughts were made up of remembrances, and they carried me up to the surface of the globe of which I ought never to have taken leave. The house in the Königstrasse, my poor dear Gräuben, that kind soul Martha, flitted like visions before my eyes, and in the dismal moanings which from time to time reached my ears I thought I could distinguish the roar of the traffic of the great cities upon earth.
children.prevalue: As for me my thoughts were made up of remembrances and they carried me up to the surface of the globe of which I ought never to have taken leave The house in the Königstrasse my poor dear Gräuben that kind soul Martha flitted like visions before my eyes and in the dismal moanings which from time to time reached my ears I thought I could distinguish the roar of the traffic of the great cities upon earth

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: My uncle still had his eye upon his work. Torch in hand, he tried to gather some idea of our situation from the observation of the strata. This calculation could, at best, be but a vague approximation; but a learned man is always a philosopher when he succeeds in remaining cool, and assuredly Professor Liedenbrock possessed this quality to a surprising degree.
children.prevalue: My uncle still had his eye upon his work Torch in hand he tried to gather some idea of our situation from the observation of the strata This calculation could at best be but a vague approximation but a learned man is always a philosopher when he succeeds in remaining cool and assuredly Professor Liedenbrock possessed this quality to a surprising degree

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I could hear him murmuring geological terms. I could understand them, and in spite of myself I felt interested in this last geological study.
children.prevalue: I could hear him murmuring geological terms I could understand them and in spite of myself I felt interested in this last geological study

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Eruptive granite, he was saying. We are still in the primitive period. But we are going up, up, higher still. Who can tell?
children.prevalue: Eruptive granite he was saying We are still in the primitive period But we are going up up higher still Who can tell

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Ah! who can tell? With his hand he was examining the perpendicular wall, and in a few more minutes he continued:
children.prevalue: Ah who can tell With his hand he was examining the perpendicular wall and in a few more minutes he continued

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: This is gneiss! here is mica schist! Ah! presently we shall come to the transition period, and then--
children.prevalue: This is gneiss here is mica schist Ah presently we shall come to the transition period and then

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: What did the Professor mean? Could he be trying to measure the thickness of the crust of the earth that lay between us and the world above? Had he any means of making this calculation? No, he had not the aneroid, and no guessing could supply its place.
children.prevalue: What did the Professor mean Could he be trying to measure the thickness of the crust of the earth that lay between us and the world above Had he any means of making this calculation No he had not the aneroid and no guessing could supply its place

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Still the temperature kept rising, and I felt myself steeped in a broiling atmosphere. I could only compare it to the heat of a furnace at the moment when the molten metal is running into the mould. Gradually we had been obliged to throw aside our coats and waistcoats, the lightest covering became uncomfortable and even painful.
children.prevalue: Still the temperature kept rising and I felt myself steeped in a broiling atmosphere I could only compare it to the heat of a furnace at the moment when the molten metal is running into the mould Gradually we had been obliged to throw aside our coats and waistcoats the lightest covering became uncomfortable and even painful

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Are we rising into a fiery furnace? I cried at one moment when the heat was redoubling.
children.prevalue: Are we rising into a fiery furnace I cried at one moment when the heat was redoubling

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: No, replied my uncle, that is impossible--quite impossible!
children.prevalue: No replied my uncle that is impossible quite impossible

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Yet, I answered, feeling the wall, this well is burning hot.
children.prevalue: Yet I answered feeling the wall this well is burning hot

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: At the same moment, touching the water, I had to withdraw my hand in haste.
children.prevalue: At the same moment touching the water I had to withdraw my hand in haste

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: The water is scalding, I cried.
children.prevalue: The water is scalding I cried

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: This time the Professor's only answer was an angry gesture.
children.prevalue: This time the Professor s only answer was an angry gesture

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Then an unconquerable terror seized upon me, from which I could no longer get free. I felt that a catastrophe was approaching before which the boldest spirit must quail. A dim, vague notion laid hold of my mind, but which was fast hardening into certainty. I tried to repel it, but it would return. I dared not express it in plain terms. Yet a few involuntary observations confirmed me in my view. By the flickering light of the torch I could distinguish contortions in the granite beds; a phenomenon was unfolding in which electricity would play the principal part; then this unbearable heat, this boiling water! I consulted the compass.

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: The compass had lost its properties! it had ceased to act properly!
children.prevalue: The compass had lost its properties it had ceased to act properly

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: SHOT OUT OF A VOLCANO AT LAST!
children.prevalue: SHOT OUT OF A VOLCANO AT LAST

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Yes: our compass was no longer a guide; the needle flew from pole to pole with a kind of frenzied impulse; it ran round the dial, and spun hither and thither as if it were giddy or intoxicated.
children.prevalue: Yes our compass was no longer a guide the needle flew from pole to pole with a kind of frenzied impulse it ran round the dial and spun hither and thither as if it were giddy or intoxicated

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: I knew quite well that according to the best received theories the mineral covering of the globe is never at absolute rest; the changes brought about by the chemical decomposition of its component parts, the agitation caused by great liquid torrents, and the magnetic currents, are continually tending to disturb it--even when living beings upon its surface may fancy that all is quiet below. A phenomenon of this kind would not have greatly alarmed me, or at any rate it would not have given rise to dreadful apprehensions.

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: But other facts, other circumstances, of a peculiar nature, came to reveal to me by degrees the true state of the case. There came incessant and continuous explosions. I could only compare them to the loud rattle of a long train of chariots driven at full speed over the stones, or a roar of unintermitting thunder.

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Then the disordered compass, thrown out of gear by the electric currents, confirmed me in a growing conviction. The mineral crust of the globe threatened to burst up, the granite foundations to come together with a crash, the fissure through which we were helplessly driven would be filled up, the void would be full of crushed fragments of rock, and we poor wretched mortals were to be buried and annihilated in this dreadful consummation.

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: My uncle, I cried, we are lost now, utterly lost!
children.prevalue: My uncle I cried we are lost now utterly lost

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What are you in a fright about now? was the calm rejoinder. What is the matter with you?
children.prevalue: What are you in a fright about now was the calm rejoinder What is the matter with you

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The matter? Look at those quaking walls! look at those shivering rocks. Don't you feel the burning heat? Don't you see how the water boils and bubbles? Are you blind to the dense vapours and steam growing thicker and denser every minute? See this agitated compass needle. It is an earthquake that is threatening us.

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: My undaunted uncle calmly shook his head.
children.prevalue: My undaunted uncle calmly shook his head

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Do you think, said he, an earthquake is coming?
children.prevalue: Do you think said he an earthquake is coming

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I do.
children.prevalue: I do

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Well, I think you are mistaken.
children.prevalue: Well I think you are mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: What! don't you recognise the symptoms?
children.prevalue: What don t you recognise the symptoms

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Of an earthquake? no! I am looking out for something better.
children.prevalue: Of an earthquake no I am looking out for something better

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: What can you mean? Explain?
children.prevalue: What can you mean Explain

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It is an eruption, Axel.
children.prevalue: It is an eruption Axel

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: An eruption! Do you mean to affirm that we are running up the shaft of a volcano?
children.prevalue: An eruption Do you mean to affirm that we are running up the shaft of a volcano

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I believe we are, said the indomitable Professor with an air of perfect self-possession; and it is the best thing that could possibly happen to us under our circumstances.
children.prevalue: I believe we are said the indomitable Professor with an air of perfect self possession and it is the best thing that could possibly happen to us under our circumstances

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The best thing! Was my uncle stark mad? What did the man mean? and what was the use of saying facetious things at a time like this?
children.prevalue: The best thing Was my uncle stark mad What did the man mean and what was the use of saying facetious things at a time like this

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What! I shouted. Are we being taken up in an eruption? Our fate has flung us here among burning lavas, molten rocks, boiling waters, and all kinds of volcanic matter; we are going to be pitched out, expelled, tossed up, vomited, spit out high into the air, along with fragments of rock, showers of ashes and scoria, in the midst of a towering rush of smoke and flames; and it is the best thing that could happen to us!

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Yes, replied the Professor, eyeing me over his spectacles, I don't see any other way of reaching the surface of the earth.
children.prevalue: Yes replied the Professor eyeing me over his spectacles I don t see any other way of reaching the surface of the earth

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I pass rapidly over the thousand ideas which passed through my mind. My uncle was right, undoubtedly right; and never had he seemed to me more daring and more confirmed in his notions than at this moment when he was calmly contemplating the chances of being shot out of a volcano!
children.prevalue: I pass rapidly over the thousand ideas which passed through my mind My uncle was right undoubtedly right and never had he seemed to me more daring and more confirmed in his notions than at this moment when he was calmly contemplating the chances of being shot out of a volcano

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: In the meantime up we went; the night passed away in continual ascent; the din and uproar around us became more and more intensified; I was stifled and stunned; I thought my last hour was approaching; and yet imagination is such a strong thing that even in this supreme hour I was occupied with strange and almost childish speculations. But I was the victim, not the master, of my own thoughts.

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: It was very evident that we were being hurried upward upon the crest of a wave of eruption; beneath our raft were boiling waters, and under these the more sluggish lava was working its way up in a heated mass, together with shoals of fragments of rock which, when they arrived at the crater, would be dispersed in all directions high and low. We were imprisoned in the shaft or chimney of some volcano. There was no room to doubt of that.

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: But this time, instead of Snæfell, an extinct volcano, we were inside one in full activity. I wondered, therefore, where could this mountain be, and in what part of the world we were to be shot out.
children.prevalue: But this time instead of Snæfell an extinct volcano we were inside one in full activity I wondered therefore where could this mountain be and in what part of the world we were to be shot out

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I made no doubt but that it would be in some northern region. Before its disorders set in, the needle had never deviated from that direction. From Cape Saknussemm we had been carried due north for hundreds of leagues. Were we under Iceland again? Were we destined to be thrown up out of Hecla, or by which of the seven other fiery craters in that island? Within a radius of five hundred leagues to the west I remembered under this parallel of latitude only the imperfectly known volcanoes of the north-east coast of America. To the east there was only one in the 80th degree of north latitude, the Esk in Jan Mayen Island, not far from Spitzbergen! Certainly there was no lack of craters, and there were some capacious enough to throw out a whole army! But I wanted to know which of them was to serve us for an exit from the inner world.

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Towards morning the ascending movement became accelerated. If the heat increased, instead of diminishing, as we approached nearer to the surface of the globe, this effect was due to local causes alone, and those volcanic. The manner of our locomotion left no doubt in my mind. An enormous force, a force of hundreds of atmospheres, generated by the extreme pressure of confined vapours, was driving us irresistibly forward. But to what numberless dangers it exposed us!

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Soon lurid lights began to penetrate the vertical gallery which widened as we went up. Right and left I could see deep channels, like huge tunnels, out of which escaped dense volumes of smoke; tongues of fire lapped the walls, which crackled and sputtered under the intense heat.
children.prevalue: Soon lurid lights began to penetrate the vertical gallery which widened as we went up Right and left I could see deep channels like huge tunnels out of which escaped dense volumes of smoke tongues of fire lapped the walls which crackled and sputtered under the intense heat

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: See, see, my uncle! I cried.
children.prevalue: See see my uncle I cried

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Well, those are only sulphureous flames and vapours, which one must expect to see in an eruption. They are quite natural.
children.prevalue: Well those are only sulphureous flames and vapours which one must expect to see in an eruption They are quite natural

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: But suppose they should wrap us round.
children.prevalue: But suppose they should wrap us round

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: But they won't wrap us round.
children.prevalue: But they won t wrap us round

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: But we shall be stifled.
children.prevalue: But we shall be stifled

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: We shall not be stifled at all. The gallery is widening, and if it becomes necessary, we shall abandon the raft, and creep into a crevice.
children.prevalue: We shall not be stifled at all The gallery is widening and if it becomes necessary we shall abandon the raft and creep into a crevice

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: But the water--the rising water?
children.prevalue: But the water the rising water

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: There is no more water, Axel; only a lava paste, which is bearing us up on its surface to the top of the crater.
children.prevalue: There is no more water Axel only a lava paste which is bearing us up on its surface to the top of the crater

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The liquid column had indeed disappeared, to give place to dense and still boiling eruptive matter of all kinds. The temperature was becoming unbearable. A thermometer exposed to this atmosphere would have marked 150°. The perspiration streamed from my body. But for the rapidity of our ascent we should have been suffocated.

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: But the Professor gave up his idea of abandoning the raft, and it was well he did. However roughly joined together, those planks afforded us a firmer support than we could have found anywhere else.
children.prevalue: But the Professor gave up his idea of abandoning the raft and it was well he did However roughly joined together those planks afforded us a firmer support than we could have found anywhere else

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: About eight in the morning a new incident occurred. The upward movement ceased. The raft lay motionless.
children.prevalue: About eight in the morning a new incident occurred The upward movement ceased The raft lay motionless

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: What is this? I asked, shaken by this sudden stoppage as if by a shock.
children.prevalue: What is this I asked shaken by this sudden stoppage as if by a shock

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: It is a halt, replied my uncle.
children.prevalue: It is a halt replied my uncle

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Is the eruption checked? I asked.
children.prevalue: Is the eruption checked I asked

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: I hope not.
children.prevalue: I hope not

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I rose, and tried to look around me. Perhaps the raft itself, stopped in its course by a projection, was staying the volcanic torrent. If this were the case we should have to release it as soon as possible.
children.prevalue: I rose and tried to look around me Perhaps the raft itself stopped in its course by a projection was staying the volcanic torrent If this were the case we should have to release it as soon as possible

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: But it was not so. The blast of ashes, scorix, and rubbish had ceased to rise.
children.prevalue: But it was not so The blast of ashes scorix and rubbish had ceased to rise

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Has the eruption stopped? I cried.
children.prevalue: Has the eruption stopped I cried

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Ah! said my uncle between his clenched teeth, you are afraid. But don't alarm yourself--this lull cannot last long. It has lasted now five minutes, and in a short time we shall resume our journey to the mouth of the crater.
children.prevalue: Ah said my uncle between his clenched teeth you are afraid But don t alarm yourself this lull cannot last long It has lasted now five minutes and in a short time we shall resume our journey to the mouth of the crater

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: As he spoke, the Professor continued to consult his chronometer, and he was again right in his prognostications. The raft was soon hurried and driven forward with a rapid but irregular movement, which lasted about ten minutes, and then stopped again.
children.prevalue: As he spoke the Professor continued to consult his chronometer and he was again right in his prognostications The raft was soon hurried and driven forward with a rapid but irregular movement which lasted about ten minutes and then stopped again

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Very good, said my uncle; in ten minutes more we shall be off again, for our present business lies with an intermittent volcano. It gives us time now and then to take breath.
children.prevalue: Very good said my uncle in ten minutes more we shall be off again for our present business lies with an intermittent volcano It gives us time now and then to take breath

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: This was perfectly true. When the ten minutes were over we started off again with renewed and increased speed. We were obliged to lay fast hold of the planks of the raft, not to be thrown off. Then again the paroxysm was over.
children.prevalue: This was perfectly true When the ten minutes were over we started off again with renewed and increased speed We were obliged to lay fast hold of the planks of the raft not to be thrown off Then again the paroxysm was over

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: I have since reflected upon this singular phenomenon without being able to explain it. At any rate it was clear that we were not in the main shaft of the volcano, but in a lateral gallery where there were felt recurrent tunes of reaction.
children.prevalue: I have since reflected upon this singular phenomenon without being able to explain it At any rate it was clear that we were not in the main shaft of the volcano but in a lateral gallery where there were felt recurrent tunes of reaction

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: How often this operation was repeated I cannot say. All I know is, that at each fresh impulse we were hurled forward with a greatly increased force, and we seemed as if we were mere projectiles. During the short halts we were stifled with the heat; whilst we were being projected forward the hot air almost stopped my breath. I thought for a moment how delightful it would be to find myself carried suddenly into the arctic regions, with a cold 30° below the freezing point. My overheated brain conjured up visions of white plains of cool snow, where I might roll and allay my feverish heat. Little by little my brain, weakened by so many constantly repeated shocks, seemed to be giving way altogether. But for the strong arm of Hans I should more than once have had my head broken against the granite roof of our burning dungeon.

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I have therefore no exact recollection of what took place during the following hours. I have a confused impression left of continuous explosions, loud detonations, a general shaking of the rocks all around us, and of a spinning movement with which our raft was once whirled helplessly round. It rocked upon the lava torrent, amidst a dense fall of ashes. Snorting flames darted their fiery tongues at us. There were wild, fierce puffs of stormy wind from below, resembling the blasts of vast iron furnaces blowing all at one time; and I caught a glimpse of the figure of Hans lighted up by the fire; and all the feeling I had left was just what I imagine must be the feeling of an unhappy criminal doomed to be blown away alive from the mouth of a cannon, just before the trigger is pulled, and the flying limbs and rags of flesh and skin fill the quivering air and spatter the blood-stained ground.

children.value: SUNNY LANDS IN THE BLUE MEDITERRANEAN
children.prevalue: SUNNY LANDS IN THE BLUE MEDITERRANEAN

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: When I opened my eyes again I felt myself grasped by the belt with the strong hand of our guide. With the other arm he supported my uncle. I was not seriously hurt, but I was shaken and bruised and battered all over. I found myself lying on the sloping side of a mountain only two yards from a gaping gulf, which would have swallowed me up had I leaned at all that way. Hans had saved me from death whilst I lay rolling on the edge of the crater.

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Where are we? asked my uncle irascibly, as if he felt much injured by being landed upon the earth again.

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The hunter shook his head in token of complete ignorance.
children.prevalue: The hunter shook his head in token of complete ignorance

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Is it Iceland? I asked.
children.prevalue: Is it Iceland I asked

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: _Nej,_ replied Hans.
children.prevalue: Nej replied Hans

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What! Not Iceland? cried the Professor.
children.prevalue: What Not Iceland cried the Professor

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Hans must be mistaken, I said, raising myself up.
children.prevalue: Hans must be mistaken I said raising myself up

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: This was our final surprise after all the astonishing events of our wonderful journey. I expected to see a white cone covered with the eternal snow of ages rising from the midst of the barren deserts of the icy north, faintly lighted with the pale rays of the arctic sun, far away in the highest latitudes known; but contrary to all our expectations, my uncle, the Icelander, and myself were sitting half-way down a mountain baked under the burning rays of a southern sun, which was blistering us with the heat, and blinding us with the fierce light of his nearly vertical rays.

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I could not believe my own eyes; but the heated air and the sensation of burning left me no room for doubt. We had come out of the crater half naked, and the radiant orb to which we had been strangers for two months was lavishing upon us out of his blazing splendours more of his light and heat than we were able to receive with comfort.

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: When my eyes had become accustomed to the bright light to which they had been so long strangers, I began to use them to set my imagination right. At least I would have it to be Spitzbergen, and I was in no humour to give up this notion.

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The Professor was the first to speak, and said:
children.prevalue: The Professor was the first to speak and said

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Well, this is not much like Iceland.
children.prevalue: Well this is not much like Iceland

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: But is it Jan Mayen? I asked.
children.prevalue: But is it Jan Mayen I asked

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Nor that either, he answered. This is no northern mountain; here are no granite peaks capped with snow. Look, Axel, look!
children.prevalue: Nor that either he answered This is no northern mountain here are no granite peaks capped with snow Look Axel look

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Above our heads, at a height of five hundred feet or more, we saw the crater of a volcano, through which, at intervals of fifteen minutes or so, there issued with loud explosions lofty columns of fire, mingled with pumice stones, ashes, and flowing lava. I could feel the heaving of the mountain, which seemed to breathe like a huge whale, and puff out fire and wind from its vast blowholes. Beneath, down a pretty steep declivity, ran streams of lava for eight or nine hundred feet, giving the mountain a height of about 1,300 or 1,400 feet. But the base of the mountain was hidden in a perfect bower of rich verdure, amongst which I was able to distinguish the olive, the fig, and vines, covered with their luscious purple bunches.

children.value: I was forced to confess that there was nothing arctic here.
children.prevalue: I was forced to confess that there was nothing arctic here

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: When the eye passed beyond these green surroundings it rested on a wide, blue expanse of sea or lake, which appeared to enclose this enchanting island, within a compass of only a few leagues. Eastward lay a pretty little white seaport town or village, with a few houses scattered around it, and in the harbour of which a few vessels of peculiar rig were gently swayed by the softly swelling waves. Beyond it, groups of islets rose from the smooth, blue waters, but in such numbers that they seemed to dot the sea like a shoal. To the west distant coasts lined the dim horizon, on some rose blue mountains of smooth, undulating forms; on a more distant coast arose a prodigious cone crowned on its summit with a snowy plume of white cloud. To the northward lay spread a vast sheet of water, sparkling and dancing under the hot, bright rays, the uniformity broken here and there by the topmast of a gallant ship appearing above the horizon, or a swelling sail moving slowly before the wind.

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Where are we? Where are we? I asked faintly.
children.prevalue: Where are we Where are we I asked faintly

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Hans closed his eyes with lazy indifference. What did it matter to him? My uncle looked round with dumb surprise.

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Well, whatever mountain this may be, he said at last, it is very hot here. The explosions are going on still, and I don't think it would look well to have come out by an eruption, and then to get our heads broken by bits of falling rock. Let us get down. Then we shall know better what we are about. Besides, I am starving, and parching with thirst.

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Decidedly the Professor was not given to contemplation. For my part, I could for another hour or two have forgotten my hunger and my fatigue to enjoy the lovely scene before me; but I had to follow my companions.
children.prevalue: Decidedly the Professor was not given to contemplation For my part I could for another hour or two have forgotten my hunger and my fatigue to enjoy the lovely scene before me but I had to follow my companions

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The slope of the volcano was in many places of great steepness. We slid down screes of ashes, carefully avoiding the lava streams which glided sluggishly by us like fiery serpents. As we went I chattered and asked all sorts of questions as to our whereabouts, for I was too much excited not to talk a great deal.

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: We are in Asia, I cried, on the coasts of India, in the Malay Islands, or in Oceania. We have passed through half the globe, and come out nearly at the antipodes.
children.prevalue: We are in Asia I cried on the coasts of India in the Malay Islands or in Oceania We have passed through half the globe and come out nearly at the antipodes

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: But the compass? said my uncle.
children.prevalue: But the compass said my uncle

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Ay, the compass! I said, greatly puzzled. According to the compass we have gone northward.
children.prevalue: Ay the compass I said greatly puzzled According to the compass we have gone northward

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Has it lied?
children.prevalue: Has it lied

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Surely not. Could it lie?
children.prevalue: Surely not Could it lie

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Unless, indeed, this is the North Pole!
children.prevalue: Unless indeed this is the North Pole

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Oh, no, it is not the Pole; but--
children.prevalue: Oh no it is not the Pole but

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Well, here was something that baffled us completely. I could not tell what to say.
children.prevalue: Well here was something that baffled us completely I could not tell what to say

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: But now we were coming into that delightful greenery, and I was suffering greatly from hunger and thirst. Happily, after two hours' walking, a charming country lay open before us, covered with olive trees, pomegranate trees, and delicious vines, all of which seemed to belong to anybody who pleased to claim them. Besides, in our state of destitution and famine we were not likely to be particular. Oh, the inexpressible pleasure of pressing those cool, sweet fruits to our lips, and eating grapes by mouthfuls off the rich, full bunches! Not far off, in the grass, under the delicious shade of the trees, I discovered a spring of fresh, cool water, in which we luxuriously bathed our faces, hands, and feet.

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Whilst we were thus enjoying the sweets of repose a child appeared out of a grove of olive trees.
children.prevalue: Whilst we were thus enjoying the sweets of repose a child appeared out of a grove of olive trees

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Ah! I cried, here is an inhabitant of this happy land!
children.prevalue: Ah I cried here is an inhabitant of this happy land

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: It was but a poor boy, miserably ill-clad, a sufferer from poverty, and our aspect seemed to alarm him a great deal; in fact, only half clothed, with ragged hair and beards, we were a suspicious-looking party; and if the people of the country knew anything about thieves, we were very likely to frighten them.

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Just as the poor little wretch was going to take to his heels, Hans caught hold of him, and brought him to us, kicking and struggling.
children.prevalue: Just as the poor little wretch was going to take to his heels Hans caught hold of him and brought him to us kicking and struggling

children.value: My uncle began to encourage him as well as he could, and said to him in good German:
children.prevalue: My uncle began to encourage him as well as he could and said to him in good German

children.prevalue: Was heiszt diesen Berg mein Knablein Sage mir geschwind

children.value: (What is this mountain called, my little friend?)
children.prevalue: What is this mountain called my little friend

children.value: The child made no answer.
children.prevalue: The child made no answer

children.name: Paragraph_42

children.prevalue: Very well said my uncle I infer that we are not in Germany

children.prevalue: He put the same question in English

children.value: We got no forwarder. I was a good deal puzzled.
children.prevalue: We got no forwarder I was a good deal puzzled

children.value: Is the child dumb? cried the Professor, who, proud of his knowledge of many languages, now tried French: _Comment appellet-on cette montagne, mon enfant?_

children.value: Silence still.
children.prevalue: Silence still

children.value: Now let us try Italian, said my uncle; and he said:
children.prevalue: Now let us try Italian said my uncle and he said

children.prevalue: Dove noi siamo

children.value: Yes, where are we? I impatiently repeated.
children.prevalue: Yes where are we I impatiently repeated

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: But there was no answer still.
children.prevalue: But there was no answer still

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Will you speak when you are told? exclaimed my uncle, shaking the urchin by the ears. _Come si noma questa isola?_

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: STROMBOLI, replied the little herdboy, slipping out of Hans' hands, and scudding into the plain across the olive trees.
children.prevalue: STROMBOLI replied the little herdboy slipping out of Hans hands and scudding into the plain across the olive trees

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: We were hardly thinking of that. Stromboli! What an effect this unexpected name produced upon my mind! We were in the midst of the Mediterranean Sea, on an island of the Æolian archipelago, in the ancient Strongyle, where Æolus kept the winds and the storms chained up, to be let loose at his will. And those distant blue mountains in the east were the mountains of Calabria. And that threatening volcano far away in the south was the fierce Etna.

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Stromboli, Stromboli! I repeated.
children.prevalue: Stromboli Stromboli I repeated

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: My uncle kept time to my exclamations with hands and feet, as well as with words. We seemed to be chanting in chorus!
children.prevalue: My uncle kept time to my exclamations with hands and feet as well as with words We seemed to be chanting in chorus

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: What a journey we had accomplished! How marvellous! Having entered by one volcano, we had issued out of another more than two thousand miles from Snæfell and from that barren, far-away Iceland! The strange chances of our expedition had carried us into the heart of the fairest region in the world. We had exchanged the bleak regions of perpetual snow and of impenetrable barriers of ice for those of brightness and 'the rich hues of all glorious things.' We had left over our heads the murky sky and cold fogs of the frigid zone to revel under the azure sky of Italy!

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: After our delicious repast of fruits and cold, clear water we set off again to reach the port of Stromboli. It would not have been wise to tell how we came there. The superstitious Italians would have set us down for fire-devils vomited out of hell; so we presented ourselves in the humble guise of shipwrecked mariners. It was not so glorious, but it was safer.

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: On my way I could hear my uncle murmuring: But the compass! that compass! It pointed due north. How are we to explain that fact?
children.prevalue: On my way I could hear my uncle murmuring But the compass that compass It pointed due north How are we to explain that fact

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: My opinion is, I replied disdainfully, that it is best not to explain it. That is the easiest way to shelve the difficulty.
children.prevalue: My opinion is I replied disdainfully that it is best not to explain it That is the easiest way to shelve the difficulty

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Indeed, sir! The occupant of a professorial chair at the Johannæum unable to explain the reason of a cosmical phenomenon! Why, it would be simply disgraceful!
children.prevalue: Indeed sir The occupant of a professorial chair at the Johannæum unable to explain the reason of a cosmical phenomenon Why it would be simply disgraceful

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: And as he spoke, my uncle, half undressed, in rags, a perfect scarecrow, with his leathern belt around him, settling his spectacles upon his nose and looking learned and imposing, was himself again, the terrible German professor of mineralogy.
children.prevalue: And as he spoke my uncle half undressed in rags a perfect scarecrow with his leathern belt around him settling his spectacles upon his nose and looking learned and imposing was himself again the terrible German professor of mineralogy

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: One hour after we had left the grove of olives, we arrived at the little port of San Vicenzo, where Hans claimed his thirteen week's wages, which was counted out to him with a hearty shaking of hands all round.
children.prevalue: One hour after we had left the grove of olives we arrived at the little port of San Vicenzo where Hans claimed his thirteen week s wages which was counted out to him with a hearty shaking of hands all round

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: At that moment, if he did not share our natural emotion, at least his countenance expanded in a manner very unusual with him, and while with the ends of his fingers he lightly pressed our hands, I believe he smiled.
children.prevalue: At that moment if he did not share our natural emotion at least his countenance expanded in a manner very unusual with him and while with the ends of his fingers he lightly pressed our hands I believe he smiled

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: ALL'S WELL THAT ENDS WELL
children.prevalue: ALL S WELL THAT ENDS WELL

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Such is the conclusion of a history which I cannot expect everybody to believe, for some people will believe nothing against the testimony of their own experience. However, I am indifferent to their incredulity, and they may believe as much or as little as they please.
children.prevalue: Such is the conclusion of a history which I cannot expect everybody to believe for some people will believe nothing against the testimony of their own experience However I am indifferent to their incredulity and they may believe as much or as little as they please

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The Stromboliotes received us kindly as shipwrecked mariners. They gave us food and clothing. After waiting forty-eight hours, on the 31 st of August, a small craft took us to Messina, where a few days' rest completely removed the effect of our fatigues.

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: On Friday, September the 4th, we embarked on the steamer Volturno, employed by the French Messageries Imperiales, and in three days more we were at Marseilles, having no care on our minds except that abominable deceitful compass, which we had mislaid somewhere and could not now examine; but its inexplicable behaviour exercised my mind fearfully. On the 9th of September, in the evening, we arrived at Hamburg.

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I cannot describe to you the astonishment of Martha or the joy of Gräuben.
children.prevalue: I cannot describe to you the astonishment of Martha or the joy of Gräuben

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Now you are a hero, Axel, said to me my blushing _fiancée,_ my betrothed, you will not leave me again!
children.prevalue: Now you are a hero Axel said to me my blushing fiancée my betrothed you will not leave me again

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I looked tenderly upon her, and she smiled through her tears.
children.prevalue: I looked tenderly upon her and she smiled through her tears

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: How can I describe the extraordinary sensation produced by the return of Professor Liedenbrock? Thanks to Martha's ineradicable tattling, the news that the Professor had gone to discover a way to the centre of the earth had spread over the whole civilised world. People refused to believe it, and when they saw him they would not believe him any the more. Still, the appearance of Hans, and sundry pieces of intelligence derived from Iceland, tended to shake the confidence of the unbelievers.

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Then my uncle became a great man, and I was now the nephew of a great man--which is not a privilege to be despised.
children.prevalue: Then my uncle became a great man and I was now the nephew of a great man which is not a privilege to be despised

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Hamburg gave a grand fete in our honour. A public audience was given to the Professor at the Johannæum, at which he told all about our expedition, with only one omission, the unexplained and inexplicable behaviour of our compass. On the same day, with much state, he deposited in the archives of the city the now famous document of Saknussemm, and expressed his regret that circumstances over which he had no control had prevented him from following to the very centre of the earth the track of the learned Icelander. He was modest notwithstanding his glory, and he was all the more famous for his humility.

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: So much honour could not but excite envy. There were those who envied him his fame; and as his theories, resting upon known facts, were in opposition to the systems of science upon the question of the central fire, he sustained with his pen and by his voice remarkable discussions with the learned of every country.

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: For my part I cannot agree with his theory of gradual cooling: in spite of what I have seen and felt, I believe, and always shall believe, in the central heat. But I admit that certain circumstances not yet sufficiently understood may tend to modify in places the action of natural phenomena.

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: While these questions were being debated with great animation, my uncle met with a real sorrow. Our faithful Hans, in spite of our entreaties, had left Hamburg; the man to whom we owed all our success and our lives too would not suffer us to reward him as we could have wished. He was seized with the mal de pays, a complaint for which we have not even a name in English.

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: _Farval,_ said he one day; and with that simple word he left us and sailed for Rejkiavik, which he reached in safety.

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: We were strongly attached to our brave eider-down hunter; though far away in the remotest north, he will never be forgotten by those whose lives he protected, and certainly I shall not fail to endeavour to see him once more before I die.

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: To conclude, I have to add that this 'Journey into the Interior of the Earth' created a wonderful sensation in the world. It was translated into all civilised languages. The leading newspapers extracted the most interesting passages, which were commented upon, picked to pieces, discussed, attacked, and defended with equal enthusiasm and determination, both by believers and sceptics. Rare privilege! my uncle enjoyed during his lifetime the glory he had deservedly won; and he may even boast the distinguished honour of an offer from Mr. Barnum, to exhibit him on most advantageous terms in all the principal cities in the United States!

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: But there was one 'dead fly' amidst all this glory and honour; one fact, one incident, of the journey remained a mystery. Now to a man eminent for his learning, an unexplained phenomenon is an unbearable hardship. Well! it was yet reserved for my uncle to be completely happy.

children.value: One day, while arranging a collection of minerals in his cabinet, I noticed in a corner this unhappy compass, which we had long lost sight of; I opened it, and began to watch it.
